title: Youngblood v. County of Charleston
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.

  
    
      
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals
S.W. Youngblood, W.M. & L.M. Loud, J.P &
T.J. Verkaik, A.E. & R.B. Wilson, C.J. & S.O. Anderson, and K.H. &
L.W. Svendsen, Respondents,
v.
County of Charleston, a political subdivision of the State of South Carolina,
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Mikell R. Scarborough, Master In Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-373
Heard October 12, 2006 â€“ Filed November 2, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Bernard E. Ferrara, Jr. and Joseph Dawson, III, both of N. Charleston, for Appellant.Â  
Melvin Richardson Hyman, Jr., of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this property action, Charleston County appeals the order finding it failed to establish ownership of a right of way through public dedication.Â  The county also contends the master erred in finding the plat was not properly indexed and therefore did not provide Respondents with notice of the right of way.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTS
In 1980, Alonzo Rouse owned land in Charleston County adjacent to several thousand acres owned by Georgia Pacific Corporation. Â Rouse wanted to subdivide his land into several lots along a road then known as Old Sambo Road, now known as Julius Robertson Road.Â  In order to do so however, Charleston County regulations required frontage on a publicly dedicated fifty-foot right of way.Â  At the time, only a twenty-foot right of way existed.Â  
On October 21, 1981, Herbert Sass wrote a letter on behalf of Rouse to Richard George, General Manager of Georgia Pacific, seeking a thirty-foot dedication in order for Rouse to meet the countyâ€™s subdivision requirements.Â  Georgia-Pacific is a Georgia company and at the time had a subsidiary, Georgia Pacific Investment Company (GPIC), an Oregon company.Â  The two companies were separate business entities that maintained separate corporate formalities; however, the companies shared a common officer, Hiram Mersereau.Â  Mersereau was senior vice president of Georgia Pacific and vice president of
GPIC.  
Apparently some confusion existed as to whether Georgia Pacific or GPIC owned the land Rouse sought for the dedication.Â  On July 13, 1981, on Rouseâ€™s behalf, Forrest Calvert prepared a plat showing the proposed right of way.Â  The plat stated â€œWE HEREBY DEDICATE . . .â€ and under the dedication appeared the words â€œGeorgia Pacific Investment Company.â€Â  Under those words appears the signature of Mersereau, purporting to dedicate the right of way in his capacity as vice president of GPIC.Â  However, Georgia Pacific, not GPIC, held legal title to the land GPIC purportedly dedicated as the right of way.Â  The dedication provided:

We hereby dedicate this 50'[1] road right-of-way . . . to the use of the public forever.Â  The owners of these lots and their heirs and assigns, guarantee its maintenance until such time as it is accepted into a public maintenance system.Â  The approval of this plat in no way obligates the County of Charleston to accept the right-of-way for maintenance or construction.Â  

On November 1, 1982, the plat was recorded in the plat index under Rouseâ€™s name.Â  On November 16, Charleston County Council approved the plat.Â  
On March 31, 1989, Georgia Pacific sold property, including the purported right of way, to Dunes West Joint Venture by special warranty deed.Â  Georgia Pacific did not exempt the purported easement from the deedâ€™s warranty provisions.Â  
Following a series of transfers that began in 1996, Beazer Homes purchased the land in 2001.Â  Beazer Homes developed and subdivided the property into six lots and sold them to Respondents by general warranty deeds. Â None of the six deeds referenced or excluded the purported right of way.Â  Since 2001, Respondents have lived in their respective homes and paid taxes on their property.Â  As late as January 2005, the county has taxed Respondentsâ€™ property, including the portion of their lots the county claims is a public right of way. Â 
In 1996, the county proposed widening Julius Robertson Road by thirty feet.Â  The portion of property on which the county intended to widen the road is in Respondentsâ€™ back yards.Â  The county claimed ownership of the property through a publicly dedicated right of way. Â 
On November 25, 2002, in response to the countyâ€™s claim of ownership, Respondents brought suit seeking a ruling that a right of way through public dedication did not exist because (1) the legal owner of the land did not perfect the dedication; and (2) the county did not accept the dedication.Â  Additionally, Respondents claimed they were bona fide purchasers without notice and were entitled to full ownership of their respective properties, including portions where the purported right of way existed.Â  
The county answered, contending inter alia, it acquired the right of way through a valid public dedication.Â  It further alleged Respondents had actual or constructive notice of the right of way because the plat was properly indexed.Â  
After a trial on March 3, 2005, the master found the county did not establish ownership of the right of way through public dedication because the legal owner of the property, Georgia Pacific, did not make the dedication.Â  Further, the master found the county did not accept the proposed dedication in 1982 because at the time, section 6-7-1070 of the South Carolina Code provided:Â  â€œThe approval of a plat by the local planning commission shall not be deemed to constitute or effect an acceptance by the municipality or the county or the public of the dedication of any street or other ground shown upon the plat.â€[2]Â  The master reasoned that even if Georgia Pacific intended to dedicate the right of way, because mere approval of the plat did not constitute acceptance, Georgia Pacific revoked the offer when it sold the land including the purported right of way.Â  Further, the master concluded the countyâ€™s 1996 directive to widen Julius Robertson Road to include the area where the purported easement existed did not constitute acceptance because nothing was left to accept since (1) Georgia Pacific sold the land and (2) acceptance was not made within a reasonable amount of time.Â  
The master also found that, assuming the county had established a valid right of way through public dedication, the right of way was invalid against Respondents by virtue of the race-notice and indexing statutes.Â  The master found the plat that created the purported right of way was not properly indexed because it was not indexed under either Georgia Pacific or GPIC as grantor or under the county as grantee.Â  Therefore, because the plat was not properly indexed, the master concluded Respondents had no notice of the right of way.Â  Accordingly, Respondents were bona fide purchasers for value without notice and the right of way could not be asserted against them.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe determination of whether property has been dedicated to the public is an action in equity.â€Â  Van Blarcum v. City of N. Myrtle Beach,  337 S.C. 446, 450, 523 S.E.2d 486, 488 (Ct. App. 1999) (citing State v. Beach Co., 271 S.C. 425, 248 S.E.2d 115 (1978)).Â  â€œBecause this is an action in equity referred to a master for final judgment, we may find facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Id. (citing Thomas v. Mitchell, 287 S.C. 35, 336 S.E.2d 154 (Ct. App. 1985)). Â 
LAW/ANALYSIS

  
  I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Public Dedication
    The county argues the master erred in finding it had not acquired a right of way through a valid public dedication.Â Â  We disagree.
    In order to determine whether property has been dedicated for public use, the party seeking to establish the dedication must show â€œ[f]irst, the owner must
    express in a positive and unmistakable manner the intention to dedicate his property to public use.Â  Second, there must be acceptance of such property by the public.â€Â  Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 326, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191-92 (1997) (citing Helsel v. City of N. Myrtle Beach, 307 S.C. 24, 413 S.E.2d 821 (1992)).Â  Further, because dedication is an â€œexceptional manner of passing an interest in land[,]â€ proof of dedication must be strict, cogent, and convincing.Â  Tupper, 326 S.C. at 326, 487 S.E.2d at 192.Â  
    Regarding the second element of perfecting a dedication, the acceptance must either be express or implied, and the acceptance must be made within a reasonable amount of time.Â  Helsel, 307 S.C. at 27, 413 S.E.2d at 823 (citing Outlaw v. Moise, 222 S.C. 24, 30, 71 S.E.2d 509, 511 (1952)).Â  Acceptance may be inferred from the publicâ€™s continuous use of the property or a public authorityâ€™s maintenance of the property.Â  Van Blarcum, 337 S.C. at 451, 523 S.E.2d at 489 (citing Tupper, 326 S.C. at 326, 487 S.E.2d at 192). 
    In the present case, the plat purportedly granted the right of way â€œto the use of the public forever.Â  The owners of these lots and their heirs and assigns, guarantee its maintenance until such time as it is accepted into a public maintenance system.â€Â  Further, the plat provides â€œ[t]he approval of this plat in no way obligates the County of Charleston to accept the right-of-way for maintenance or construction.â€Â  By the plain language of the plat, we find the dedication is to the public only.Â  The wording of the plat did not require any action on behalf of the county in order to accept the dedication.Â  Therefore, in this particular case, only the public could effectuate acceptance of the dedication and the only manner in which the public could have accepted the dedication would be through the publicâ€™s continuous use of the right of way.Â  We find no evidence suggesting the public has used the property in any manner.Â  In fact, the evidence shows that the property has been fenced off from Julius Robertson Road and used as Respondentsâ€™ respective residential back yards.Â  
    Further, although not controlling on the issue of whether dedication has been accepted, the assessment of taxes is a factor to consider along with other evidence.Â  Van Blarcum, 337 S.C. at 452, 523 S.E.2d at 489 (citation omitted).Â  Here, taken together with the other evidence showing that the disputed right of way has been used by Respondents for their own private use, the countyâ€™s continuous assessment and collection of taxes on the property prevents it from claiming the property has been accepted by the public.Â  
    Because we find there was no acceptance of the dedication, we need not address whether there was intent on the part of the actual owner, Georgia Pacific, to dedicate the property.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (finding an appellate court need not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).
    II.Â Â Â Â Â  Indexing
    The county argues the master erred in finding that even if it had established the right of way had been publicly dedicated, the county could not assert its claim of ownership against Respondents because they were bona fide purchasers for value without notice.Â  We disagree.
    Section 30-9-40 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) provides that immediately after the filing of a written instrument the register of deeds or clerk of court shall â€œenter it upon the proper indexes in his office, which constitute an integral, necessary, and inseparable part of the recordation of the deed, mortgage, or other written instrument for any and all purposes whatsoever.â€Â  Further, section 30-9-40 provides:

    The entries in the indexes required to be made are notice to all persons sufficient to put them upon inquiry as to the purport and effect of the deed, mortgage, or other written instrument so filed for
    record, but the recordation of a deed, mortgage, or other written instrument is not notice as to the purport and effect of the deed, mortgage, or other written instrument unless the filing of the instrument for record is entered as required in the indexes.

    (emphasis added).Â  According to Section 30-9-40 â€œproper indexing supplies inquiry notice of an instrument, while recordation without proper indexing supplies no notice at all.â€Â  Thomas v. Thomas, 286 S.C. 294, 298, 333 S.E.2d 76, 78 (Ct. App. 1985) (citing Bradley v. Guess, 165 S.C. 161, 163 S.E.2d 466 (1932)).Â  
    Section 30-9-10 of the South Carolina Code (Rev. 1991) establishes the manner in which to accomplish proper indexing and provides that an instrument conveying land should be indexed, alphabetically, under the names of the grantor and grantee.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 30-9-10 (â€œ[R]eference shall be had by means of two indexes, both containing the year of registry, names of parties, . . . the alphabetical arrangement of one being according to the names of the parties who executed the writings and of the other according to the names of the parties to whom they were executed.â€).Â  When construed together, sections 30-9-10 and 30-9-40 require that for an instrument conveying an interest in land to provide notice it must be indexed alphabetically under the names of both the grantee and grantor.Â  
    Here, the plat was not properly indexed because it was indexed under the name of Rouse, who was neither grantor nor grantee of the extended right of way.Â  At trial, Respondents presented Lynda Sullivan as an expert witness in the area of title examination, chain of title, and real estate closing transactions.Â  She testified the plat was not indexed under the names Georgia Pacific, GPIC, or any variation thereof.Â  Nor was the plat indexed under the countyâ€™s name as grantee.Â  She testified the plat was indexed under Rouseâ€™s name, and he was neither grantor nor grantee of the disputed right of way.Â  Further, she testified that the common practice is to search the subject property but not adjoining properties.Â  Sullivan also testified that the plat creating the purported right of way was not in the chain of title for the property.Â  After reviewing the evidence we agree the plat was not properly indexed and, therefore, did not provide Respondents with notice that the county had a right of way in the properties Respondents subsequently purchased.Â  
    CONCLUSION
    For the foregoing reasons, we find the master correctly concluded that the county failed to establish public dedication of the right of way.Â  Further, we find the plat was not properly indexed and, thus, failed to provide Respondents with notice.Â  As bona fide purchasers for value without notice, the countyâ€™s claim of ownership of the right of way cannot prevail as against Respondentsâ€™ titles.Â  The masterâ€™s order is 
    AFFIRMED.Â  
    HEARN, C.J., STILWELL, and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  The actual purported dedication is only thirty feet.Â  
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  This statue was repealed in 1999.Â  See 1994 Act No. 355, Â§ 2, effective May 3, 1999.Â

title: Tennant v. County of Georgetown
text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
James M. Tennant and Charles R. Richards, Appellants,
v.
The County of Georgetown; Edsel Hemingway, Ronald Charlton, David Hood, Johnny
Morant, Helen Rudolph, Thomas Earl Drayton, and Jerry Oakley, in their official capacities; Thomas W. Edwards, Jr., in his individual capacity; James M. Mock, Jr., in his individual capacity; Jack M.
Scoville, Jr., in his individual capacity; the Public Service Commission of South Carolina; and the South Carolina Budget and Control Board,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Georgetown County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-374
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed November 2, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Charles R. Richards, of Murrells Inlet; and James M. Tennant, of Georgetown; both pro se Appellants.
Jack M. Scoville, Jr. and William Stuart Duncan, of Georgetown; and Edwin E. Evans, David K. Avant, and Paul M. Koch, of Columbia; for Respondents. 
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Charles R. Richards and James M. Tennant (collectively Appellants) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to the County of Georgetown (County) and the South Carolina Budget and Control Board in Appellantsâ€™ suit seeking a declaratory judgment setting aside Countyâ€™s 911 Ordinance.[1]Â  In addition, Appellants appeal the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment to Jack M. Scoville, Jr. for abuse of process, and Scoville, Thomas W. Edwards, Jr., and James M. Mock, Jr. for intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On September 18, 2001, County enacted an ordinance (the Ordinance) authorizing the collection of a $1.00 per month fee (Fee) on each telephone line within its jurisdiction to fund improvements to its Emergency 911 System. Â The Ordinance does not specifically direct how the Fee will be spent.Â  To authorize expenditures from money raised with the Fee, County created a proposed â€œEnhanced 911 System Planâ€ (the Plan).Â  On November 16, 2002, the County submitted the Plan, which showed a revenue surplus, to the Office of Information Resource of the State Budget and Control Board (the Board) for approval.Â  
Before the Board approved the Plan, Appellants filed suit seeking a declaratory judgment of the illegality of the Fee, arguing it would be used to fund a radio communications system allegedly unauthorized by statute.Â  While the record shows the County considered funding this system using the Fee, the Plan submitted to the Board contained no such provision.Â  Scoville, the Countyâ€™s attorney, moved for sanctions, alleging the frivolity of the suit.Â  Appellants filed a cross-motion for sanctions against Scoville.Â  The circuit court did not grant either motion.
The County moved to dismiss the action.Â  The circuit court held a hearing and dismissed Appellantsâ€™ case without prejudice, basing its decision on the fact the Board had not considered or approved the Plan, and therefore, the controversy lacked ripeness.Â  
In the ensuing months, the County and the Board engaged in a healthy dialogue regarding the Plan.Â  Specifically, the County indicated it would seek approval for future expenditures not included in the Plan and would lower the Fee if a revenue surplus occurred.Â  Appellants also contacted the Board with respect to the Plan.Â  On July 12, 2002, the Board approved the Plan.Â  
On September 24, 2002, the County held a meeting at which it approved the expenditure of Fee revenues on the contemplated radio communications system.Â  The parties do not dispute that this radio system would be used to contact emergency response personnel after the County received a 911 call.Â  Mock, the Director of Emergency Services for the County, requested the Boardâ€™s approval for this expenditure.Â  The Board approved the proposal.Â  
In response, Appellants filed an amended complaint seeking to set aside the Fee and the Plan because the Countyâ€™s expenditure of funds on a radio system allegedly violated statutory authority.[2]Â  Appellants named Mock and Edwards, Countyâ€™s Administrator, as parties for their role in obtaining the Boardâ€™s approval.Â  Appellants argued Mock and Edwards falsified the original, unedited Plan by failing to include the proposal to use part of the funds to pay for the radio system.Â  In addition, Appellants sought a declaratory judgment that the County acted outside their statutory authority in authorizing the expenditure of the Fee on the radio system, the Board illegally approved of this expenditure, and the Public Service Commission (PSC) failed to regulate this expenditure.[3]Â  Â Â 
Moreover, Appellants alleged County violated the prior circuit court order by collecting the Fee before seeking Board approval for the radio system.Â  Furthermore, Appellants sought damages for abuse of process against Scoville and for intentional infliction of emotional distress against Scoville, Mock, and Edwards.Â  The Board answered and moved to dismiss the amended complaint.Â  Subsequently, the County, Scoville, Edwards, and Mock also answered.Â  Scoville and Edwards also filed counterclaims for libel, slander, and civil conspiracy.
On January 21, 2004, the circuit court converted the Boardâ€™s motion to dismiss into one for summary judgment.Â  Appellants moved to amend their complaint a second time, to dismiss Scovilleâ€™s and Edwardsâ€™ counterclaims, and to request a discovery conference.Â  The County, Scoville, Edwards, and Mock later moved for summary judgment.Â Â Â  
The circuit court held a hearing and granted summary judgment against Appellants on all of their causes of action.Â  In addition, the circuit court dismissed Scovilleâ€™s and Mockâ€™s counterclaims.Â  Appellants, Scoville, and Mock filed motions to reconsider.Â  The circuit court held a hearing on these motions.Â  After the hearing but before the circuit court issued a decision, Appellants filed a motion to stay the case and for recusal of the judge.Â  The circuit court denied all of Appellantsâ€™ motions but reversed its order dismissing Scovilleâ€™s and Mockâ€™s counterclaims.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
An appellate court reviews the grant of summary judgment under the same standard applied by the circuit court.Â  David v. McLeod Regâ€™l Med. Ctr., 367 S.C. 242, 247, 626 S.E.2d 1, 3 (2006).Â  The circuit court should grant summary judgment â€œif the pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file, together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law.â€ Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Byrd v. City of Hartsville, 365 S.C. 650, 656, 620 S.E.2d 76, 79 (2005).Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the evidence and all reasonable inferences therefrom must be viewed in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Law v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 368 S.C. 424, 434, 629 S.E.2d 642, 648 (2006).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. The Public Safety Communications Center Act
Appellants argue the circuit court erred in holding the Public Safety Communications Center Act, sections 23-47-10 to -80 of the South Carolina Code (Supp. 2005) (the Act), allows the County to enact the Fee and use revenues on the radio system.Â  We disagree.
This court may determine the issue of legislative intent as a matter of law.Â  Charleston County Parks & Recreation Commâ€™n v. Somers, 319 S.C. 65, 67, 459 S.E.2d 841, 843 (1995).Â  â€œWhen the language of a statute is plain, unambiguous and conveys a clear and definite meaning, the rules of statutory interpretation are unnecessary and the court may not impose another meaning.â€Â  S.C. Uninsured Employerâ€™s Fund v. House, 360 S.C. 468, 472, 602 S.E.2d 81, 83 (Ct. App. 2004).
A local government, including a county, seeking to impose a fee for its emergency telephone system, or â€œ911 system,â€ must submit a â€œ911 system planâ€ to the Board for approval.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-47-30(A) (Supp. 2005); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-47-10 (Supp. 2005) (defining â€œlocal government,â€ â€œ911 system,â€ â€œ911 system plan,â€ and other statutory terms with respect to the Act).Â  A 911 system must include â€œequipment to connect the PSAP [the facility receiving 911 calls] to all law enforcement, fire protection, and emergency medical or rescue agencies, or both . . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-47-20(C)(2) (amended by Act No. 317, 2006 S.C. Acts 317, effective May 30, 2006).Â  
To help fund its 911 system, a local government may adopt an ordinance imposing a monthly fee on telephone lines within the locality.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 23-47-40(A) (Supp. 2005).Â  This fee may be used only to pay for certain enumerated items, including â€œitems necessary to meet the standards outlined . . . specifically in Section 23-47-20(C) . . . .â€Â  Â§ 23-47-40(B).Â  Â Â 
In this case, the County adopted an ordinance pursuant to section 23-47-40(A) to establish the Fee.Â  The County then submitted the Plan to the Board to comply with section 23-47-30(A).Â  After the Board approved the Plan, the County sought to spend revenue from the Fee on the radio system to allow its PSAP to directly contact and dispatch local emergency responders.Â  Appellants specifically contend the County cannot spend the Fee on the radio system because (1) the Act only allows this type of revenue to be spent on telephone communications; (2) the radio system might be used for other types of communication apart from contacting emergency response personnel; and (3) the PSC must approve of all equipment upon which the County spends this type of revenue. Â 
Section 23-47-20(C)(2) does not limit the type of equipment required to connect the PSAP to emergency responders.Â  Accordingly, we refuse to read a limitation requiring only telephone equipment be used.Â  We also find no limitation in the Act requiring the equipment used in section 23-47-20(C)(2) be used only to connect the PSAP to emergency personnel.[4]Â  Furthermore, the Act does not require the PSC to regulate the equipment designated in section 23-47-20(C)(2).Â  Based on the foregoing, we hold the circuit court properly granted summary judgment to the County and the Board on Appellantsâ€™ declaratory judgment action.
Appellants also argue the circuit court erred in finding a Board employeeâ€™s letter interpreting the Act and an informal opinion made by an assistant attorney general supported its decision.Â  Because we hold the Act plainly allows the expenditure here, we decline to address these issues.
II. Abuse of Process
Appellants contend the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment on their abuse of process claim.Â  We disagree.
The essential elements of abuse of process are an ulterior purpose and a willful act in the use of the process not proper in the conduct of the proceeding.Â  Hainer v. Am. Med. Intâ€™l, Inc., 328 S.C. 128, 136, 492 S.E.2d 103, 107 (1997).Â  Appellants merely argue Scoville acted outside the scope of his authority in bringing the sanctions motion in Appellantsâ€™ first suit.Â  Appellants do not argue Scoville had an ulterior purpose in filing this motion or that the motion was improper in the conduct of the proceeding.Â  Accordingly, we hold the circuit court properly granted summary judgment on Appellantsâ€™ abuse of process claim.
III. Intentional Infliction of Emotional Distress
Appellants claim the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment on their claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  We disagree.
A personâ€™s willful, malicious conduct proximately causing anotherâ€™s emotional distress may be actionable as
intentional infliction of emotional distress or the tort of outrage.Â  Williams v. Lancaster County Sch. Dist., 369 S.C. 293, ___, 631 S.E.2d 286, 293 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  To state a claim for intentional infliction of emotional distress, a plaintiff must show (1) the defendant intentionally or recklessly inflicted severe emotional distress, or was certain or substantially certain that such distress would result from his conduct; (2) the conduct was so extreme and outrageous as to exceed all possible bounds of decency and must be regarded as atrocious and utterly intolerable in a civilized community; (3) the actions of defendant caused the plaintiffâ€™s emotional distress; and (4) the emotional distress suffered by the plaintiff was so severe that no reasonable person could be expected to endure it.Â  Bergstrom v. Palmetto Health Alliance, 358 S.C. 388, 401, 596 S.E.2d 42, 48 (2004).Â  â€œThe court determines, in the first instance, whether the defendantâ€™s conduct may reasonably be regarded as sufficiently extreme and outrageous to permit recovery.Â  Only when reasonable persons may differ will the question proceed to the jury.â€Â Â  Brown v. Pearson, 326 S.C. 409, 424, 483 S.E.2d 477, 485 (Ct. App. 1997).
Appellants allege the actions of Scoville, Mock, and Edwards in filing a motion for sanctions and â€œillegallyâ€ or â€œfraudulentlyâ€ seeking the Boardâ€™s approval to use the Fee to pay for a radio system caused them emotional distress.Â  As a matter of law, we hold this conduct is not sufficiently extreme or outrageous to permit recovery.Â  
IV. Genuine Issues of Material Fact
Appellants argue the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment because genuine issues of material fact exist.Â  We disagree.
Initially, Appellants assert the legislative intent behind the Act creates a genuine issue of material fact.Â  However, South Carolina has long recognized the determination of legislative intent is a matter of law for the courts.Â  See, e.g., Wehle v. S.C. Ret. Sys., 363 S.C. 394, 403, 611 S.E.2d 240, 244 (2005).Â  
Appellants next argue â€œthe mere existence of the disputed Ted Lightle letter is a genuine issue of material fact.â€Â  The existence of this letter, contained in the record, does not appear to be disputed by either party.Â  
Finally, Appellants claim Scovilleâ€™s assertion at the circuit courtâ€™s hearing on summary judgment that the Countyâ€™s radio system would be used at least fifty percent of the time for 911 purposes generated a genuine issue of material fact.Â  However, this assertion is irrelevant to the present controversy because, as we have stated, the Act does not require such a showing.
V. Discovery
Appellants argue the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment before allowing them to complete discovery.Â  We disagree.
â€œSince it is a drastic remedy, summary judgment â€˜should be cautiously invoked so that no person will be improperly deprived of a trial of the disputed factual issues.â€™ â€Â  Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 112, 410 S.E.2d 537, 543 (1991) (quoting Watson v. S. Ry. Co., 420 F.Supp. 483, 486 (D.S.C. 1975)).Â  â€œThis means, among other things, that summary judgment must not be granted until the opposing party has had a full and fair opportunity to complete discovery.â€Â  Baughman, 306 S.C. at 112, 410 S.E.2d at 543.Â  In making this determination, the circuit court should consider whether the party opposing summary judgment can â€œ[demonstrate] a likelihood that further discovery will uncover additional evidence relevant to the issue . . . and [the party is] not merely engaged in a â€˜fishing expedition.â€™ â€Â  Id.
Here, Appellants filed a request for a discovery conference, listing several proposed depositions and explaining three issues they wanted to explore.Â  Appellants sought information with respect to the scope of Scovilleâ€™s, Mockâ€™s, and Edwardsâ€™ authority; efforts made by the PSC, the Board, and the County to comply with the circuit courtâ€™s decree dismissing Appellantsâ€™ original claims without prejudice; and efforts made by the PSC, the Board, and the County to comply with statutory authority.Â  None of these issues are relevant to the outcome of this case.Â  Accordingly, we hold the circuit court properly granted summary judgment without allowing this discovery request.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
VI. Miscellaneous Factual Issues
Appellants argue the circuit court erred in finding the County could not afford the radio system without using the Fee and holding improvements to the 911 system could not be accomplished without the radio system.Â  These findings of fact are irrelevant to this appeal.Â  The Act does not require either of these findings before the County may spend 911 funds on the radio system.Â  â€œ[W]hatever doesnâ€™t make any difference, doesnâ€™t matter.â€Â 
McCall v. Finley, 294 S.C. 1, 4, 362 S.E.2d 26, 28 (Ct. App. 1987).
VII. Fraudulent Conduct
Appellants claim the circuit court erred in granting summary judgment because evidence exists that the County made misrepresentations and submitted fraudulent documents to the Board.Â  We disagree.
Essentially, Appellants argue the County was required to submit its proposal to use the Fee for a radio system at the same time it submitted the Plan.Â  Consequently, they contend the failure of the County to mention the proposed radio system to the Board at the time it submitted the Plan constituted misrepresentation or fraud.Â  Appellants cite no authority for their proposition that the County had to include information about the radio system in their submission to the Board, nor do we find any.Â  See First Sav. Bank v. McLean, 314 S.C. 361, 363, 444 S.E.2d 513, 514 (1994) (holding when an appellant does not argue or provide supporting authority for his assertion, he abandons the assertion).Â  In addition, Appellants presented no evidence of any fraud or misrepresentation.Â  Therefore, we hold the circuit court properly held no evidence existed of fraud or misrepresentation. 
VIII. Motion to Amend
Appellants argue the circuit court erred in denying their motion to amend the complaint.Â  We disagree.
â€œ[A] motion to amend a pleading is addressed to the discretion of the trial judge, and the party opposing the motion has the burden of establishing prejudice.â€Â  Stanley v. Kirkpatrick, 357 S.C. 169, 174, 592 S.E.2d 296, 298 (2004).Â  According to Appellantsâ€™ argument on appeal, the circuit court dismissed their cause of action for contempt and dismissed the PSC as a party.[5]Â  The preamble to Appellantsâ€™ second amended complaint explains they desired to rename the PSC as a party and include two causes of action replacing the contempt claim.Â  Because the circuit courtâ€™s order is not included in the record, this Court cannot determine whether the dismissal was with or without prejudice.Â  â€œIt is the
appellantâ€™s burden to present a sufficient record for appellate review.â€Â  Webb v. CSX Transp., Inc., 364 S.C. 639, 655, 615 S.E.2d 440, 449 (2005).Â  Â Â 
Moreover, Appellants sought to name Jeffrey K. Herron, the employee of the Board who approved of the Countyâ€™s proposals, and the Director of the PSC as parties.Â  The substance of Appellantsâ€™ allegations against these parties is the same as those leveled at the Board and the PSC.Â  We reiterate these allegations are unmeritorious.Â  Therefore, we hold the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in denying Appellantsâ€™ motion to amend.
IX. Motion to Recuse
Appellants claim the circuit court erred in denying their motion to recuse.Â  We disagree.
The decision to recuse rests within the trial judgeâ€™s discretion.Â  Ness v. Eckerd Corp., 350 S.C. 399, 404, 566 S.E.2d 193, 196 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  â€œWhen no evidence is presented other than claimed â€˜adverseâ€™ rulings by the judge, the judge is not required to recuse himself.â€Â  Reading v. Ball, 291 S.C. 492, 494, 354 S.E.2d 397, 398 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  However, a judgeâ€™s impartiality might reasonably be questioned when his factual findings are not supported by the record.Â  Ellis v. Procter & Gamble Distrib. Co., 315 S.C. 283, 285, 433 S.E.2d 856, 857 (1993).
Appellants argue the judgeâ€™s comments asking the Board for an affidavit and the judgeâ€™s ruling that the Act authorized the Countyâ€™s expenditure on a radio system show the judgeâ€™s partiality.Â  Additionally, Appellants contend the judge showed prejudice when he remarked about the propriety of combining a declaratory judgment action with a tort action.Â  The affidavit, which the Board later submitted, simply restated the Boardâ€™s position that the radio system had been approved.Â  However, the parties did not dispute whether the Board approved this expenditure.Â  Moreover, the judgeâ€™s ruling that the Act authorized Countyâ€™s expenditure has been affirmed by this court.Â  Furthermore, the judge never prevented Appellants from arguing all of their causes of action.Â  Accordingly, we find the judge did not err in failing to recuse himself.[6]  
X. Scovilleâ€™s and Edwardsâ€™ Counterclaims
Appellants argue the circuit court erred in reversing its grant of summary judgment with respect to Scovilleâ€™s and Edwardsâ€™ counterclaims.Â  A party may not appeal the denial of summary judgment, even when combined with an appeal of a final order.Â  Olson v. Faculty House of Carolina, Inc., 354 S.C. 161, 167, 580 S.E.2d 440, 443 (2003).Â  Therefore, we do not address this issue.
CONCLUSION
We hold the plain language of the Act allows the County to spend revenues from the Fee on a radio communications system intended to allow its PSAP to contact and dispatch emergency personnel.Â  In addition, we find Appellants failed to state causes of action for abuse of process or intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  Appellantsâ€™ other factual allegations are irrelevant to this appeal.Â  
We further hold Appellants failed to show any genuine issues of material fact or a need for further discovery.Â  Moreover, the circuit court did not abuse its discretion in denying Appellantsâ€™ motion to amend or motion to recuse.Â  Finally, we refuse to address Appellantsâ€™ appeal from a denial of summary judgment.Â  Accordingly, the circuit courtâ€™s order is 
AFFIRMED.[7]
GOOLSBY, BEATTY, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Appellants included several members of Countyâ€™s council in their complaint.Â  Because they are named in their official capacities, we include them as part of County.
[2] Appellants do not include their original complaint in the record.Â  
[3] A previous circuit court order, not included in the record, dismisses PSC as a party.Â  (R.95).
[4] Alternatively, Appellants argue a 1992 letter from a Board employee requires at least fifty percent of the radio systemâ€™s use be for 911 purposes.Â  No such limitation exists within the Act.
[5] Appellants do not include this order in the record.
[6] Appellants also appeal the circuit courtâ€™s denial of their motion to stay the present action and argue the judge lacked impartiality.Â  We find these issues subsumed within Appellantsâ€™ argument the judge should have recused himself.Â  Accordingly, our holding with respect to recusal is dispositive.Â  
[7] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

title: Jones v. Daley
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Brenda Jones Appellant,
v.
Lake Daley Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Jasper County
C. Stephen Bennett, Special Referee

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-376
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed November 17, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
David S. Mathews, of Ridgeland, for Appellant.
R. Thayer Rivers, of Ridgeland, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Brenda Jones appeals the special refereeâ€™s order finding that her use (along with that of her predecessors in ownership) of Lake Daleyâ€™s property for ingress and egress to her adjoining property did not create an easement by prescription.Â  The special referee found Jones failed to prove twenty years of continuous usage of the alleged easement.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
This case comes to us on appeal for a second time, having previously been reversed by the court of appeals and remanded to the special referee for a determination as to whether the use of the alleged easement by Jones and her predecessors was continuous for a twenty year period.Â  While new testimony, evidence, and arguments were presented at the second hearing, on remand, the transcript and exhibits of the first hearing were also available for consideration by the special referee.
The alleged dominant property (â€œthe Jones Parcelâ€) is a five acre tract of land in Jasper County acquired by Brenda Jonesâ€™ great uncle, Thomas Washington, in 1939. Â In 1963, Thomas gave this parcel to his daughter, Jonesâ€™ aunt Jannie Washington.Â  Ms. Washington granted the property to Jones, transferring a one-half interest in 1982 and the remaining half in 1993.
The alleged servient land (â€œthe Daley Parcelâ€) is a two hundred acre tract, located, in part, on the western boundary of Jonesâ€™ property.Â  At the time of Thomas Washingtonâ€™s acquisition of the Jones Parcel, the Daley Parcel was owned by Union Camp.Â  In 1987, the land was sold to Delta Plantation and was subsequently purchased by Lake Daley in the late 1990s. 
Throughout the Washington/Jones familyâ€™s ownership of the Jones Parcel, the property has been landlocked.Â  However, the land was accessed by means of other surrounding properties.Â  When, where, how, and to what frequency this land was accessed is central to this dispute.Â  
One possible means of access to the property was by use of a trail that followed the northern and eastern boundary of the Daley Parcel and the nearest public road, located to the west of both properties. Â This path, which follows the outer borders of the Daley Parcel but is situated entirely within its boundaries, is the alleged prescriptive easement and the route that Jones asserts was used continuously for a period of twenty years.Â  According to the testimony of Jones and her witnesses, this path existed since the time of Thomas Washingtonâ€™s acquisition of the five acre property in 1939.Â  It is also their testimony that the family began using the path at that time.Â  
At some point in the early 1950s, Union Camp began periodically plowing the preexisting access trail for the purpose of creating a firebreak or â€œfire lane.â€Â  Jones and her witnesses contend that following Union Campâ€™s tilling, the Washingtons would work the freshly plowed path with shovels, leveling out the newly cleared trail to make the path more suitable for ingress and egress to their property. Â The Washingtons never requested permission to use the trail because they believed, since the trail was the only access to their property, they had a valid legal right to maintain and use it in order to reach their land.Â  Union Camp, the owner of the Daley Parcel for most of the time period at issue, was aware of the Washingtonsâ€™ use and maintenance of the trail and fully condoned it during the time in which it was used.Â Â Â  
At the initial hearing, Jonesâ€™ uncle, Peter Washington, who worked the Jones Parcel with his father, original owner Thomas Washington, testified the family actively farmed Jones parcel from at least the late 1950s.Â  During their testimony, Jonesâ€™ other two uncles made no attempt to dispute this information.Â  In contrast to his earlier statement, during the second hearing, Peter Washington testified that his father farmed the land until the early 1980s. 
Regardless of the date, after the Washingtons ceased farming the Jones Parcel, their use of the trail became less frequent in the decades that followed.Â  They testified, however, that they continued to periodically visit the property and maintain the trail following Union Campâ€™s plowing. Â Jones, age 46, testified the trail was used by her family to access the parcel â€œas far back as [she] remembered,â€ and she specifically recalled using the access herself since the 1970s or 1980s.Â  However, because Jones did not reside in Jasper County, or even South Carolina, during her youth, her visits to the property, though numerous, were sporadic. Â Johnny Scott, a nearby resident since the 1960s, testified that the trailâ€™s use to reach â€œburiedâ€ property was common community knowledge.
In the mid-1990s, Delta Plantation, then current owner of the Daley Parcel, decided to close a road used by several other â€œburiedâ€ landowners to cross over the two hundred acre property. Â This road did not connect to the Jones Parcel.Â  To satisfy landowners who possessed recorded easements over the closed road, the northern access trail, the path used by the Washington family, was expanded into a full-sized road and all landowners with recorded easements over the closed road were granted written easements over the newly created one. Â This road did not connect to the Jones Parcel.Â  Because Jones did not have a recorded easement to use the closed road, she was not granted a written easement to use the road built over her parcelâ€™s only access.Â  
C.M. Dansler, an employee for Delta Plantation, who worked on the 1990s trail expansion, testified as to the state of the trail when they decided to build the new road.Â  He stated he had maintained and expanded the firebreak since the beginning of his employment in 1987. Â Nevertheless, when asked if the new road was built over an existing road, he stated, â€œNo . . . there was a fireline, but just barely.â€ Â Although he opined that the path was about eight feet wide in places and would be traversable by a small tractor, he testified that by the mid-90s the trail was nothing more than a â€œdeer trail.â€ 
In 2001, Jones attempted to haul timber from her parcel over the newly expanded road.Â  Daley objected to this activity.Â  In 2002, Jones brought an action against Daley to declare an easement by prescription for ingress and egress over the road.Â  The appointed special referee found no easement by prescription was created by Jones and her predecessorsâ€™ prior use.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The determination of the existence of an easement is a question of fact in an action at law. Â Slear v. Hanna, 329 S.C. 407, 496 S.E.2d 633, (1998); Jowers v.Â  Hornsby, 292 S.C. 549, 551, 357 S.E.2d 710, 711 (1987); Hartley v. John Wesley United Methodist Church of Johns Island, 355 S.C. 145, 148, 584 S.E.2d 386, 387 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In an action at law tried without a jury, the judgeâ€™s finding of fact will not be disturbed on appeal unless there is no evidence to support the judgeâ€™s findings.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 85-86, 221 S.E.2d 733, 775 (1976); Goodwin v. Johnson, 357 S.C. 49, 52-53, 591 S.E.2d 34, 36 (Ct. App. 2004); Roberts v. Gaskins, 327 S.C. 478, 486 S.E.2d 771, (Ct. App. 1997). Â Â The present matter was consensually referred to a special referee.Â  Accordingly, our scope of review is limited to the correction of errors of law, and we will not disturb the refereeâ€™s factual findings that have some evidentiary support.Â  Townes, 266 S.C. at 85-86, 221 S.E.2d at 775; Hartley, 355 S.C. at 148, 584 S.E.2d at 387. 
DISCUSSION
On appeal, Jones argues the special referee erred in finding she failed to prove her usage (and/or that of her predecessors in title) of the Daley parcel was continuous for the required period.Â  Specifically, Jones contends the only reasonable inference to be drawn from the evidence presented was that Thomas Washington and his children and grandchild used the route at issue on Daleyâ€™s land as the only means of ingress and egress to their property and that this use was continuous and without interruption for at least twenty years.Â  We disagree.
Although it is Jonesâ€™ contention that the purported easement was in use since at least 1939, the special referee found differently, ruling that at the very earliest, any use of the purported easement did not begin until 1949.Â  There is evidence in the record to support the refereeâ€™s finding.Â  
Jones and her witnesses specifically and repeatedly referenced a twenty-one acre plot of land they called â€œthe home place,â€ which bordered on the northern boundary of Daleyâ€™s property.Â  This â€œhome placeâ€ was to the north of and directly adjacent to a large section of the alleged easement that Jones claims was used to access the Jones Parcel since 1939.Â  However, the Washington/Jones family did not acquire the land referred to as the â€œhome placeâ€ until 1949.Â  An earlier, completely different â€œhome placeâ€ for the Washington/Jones family once sat directly to the east of the Daley parcel and to the south of, although not adjacent to, the Jones Parcel.Â  This earlier â€œhome placeâ€ was lost due to tax forfeiture sometime prior to the 1949 acquisition of the current â€œhome place.â€
Peter Washington testified that during his familyâ€™s ownership of the first â€œhome place,â€ he and other relatives were able to and did access the Jones Parcel by way of a different fire lane.Â  This path ran directly north from the original â€œhome placeâ€ until it reached the five acre Jones Parcel.Â  This being a different route from the one which Jones claims was used to ingress and egress the Jones Parcel from 1939 onward, there was evidence in the record to support a finding by the special referee that any use of the purported easement did not begin until, at the earliest, the Washingtonâ€™s/Jonesâ€™ acquisition of the current â€œhome placeâ€ in 1949.Â  
Although Jones argues that the evidence only allows for a conclusion that the purported easement was in use until 1980, there is evidence in the record to support the refereeâ€™s finding that continuous use of the path ceased much earlier. Â 
When asked at the first hearing, â€œSo when did yâ€™all quit farming the five acres,â€ Peter Washington responded â€œLate fiftiesâ€¦ â€™59.â€ Â In the second hearing, Mr. Washington testified that his father farmed the land until around 1980. Â Although he explained this inconsistency with his previous statement as a misunderstanding as to what was meant by the word â€œyâ€™all,â€ Mr. Washingtonâ€™s testimony provided evidence on which the special referee could find that the family ceased farming operations on the Jones Parcel in 1959, particularly in light of the fact that the referee found this inconsistency to have impeached Mr. Washington.
The special referee found â€œthere was no clear, direct and credible testimony by [Jones] and her witnesses as to dates, months, years, times or frequency of [Jonesâ€™] visitation and her predecessorâ€™s visitation to her 5 acre parcel of property by usage of the â€˜fire laneâ€™ during the periods of time in the 1960â€™s, 1970â€™s, 1980â€™s, and 1990â€™sâ€¦â€Â  There was evidence to support this finding.Â  After the point in time when her family quit farming the land, Jones presented very little evidence as to use of the path over Daley Parcel.Â  Additionally, what evidence there was, suggested only sporadic visits to the land.Â  The burden of proving a easement by prescription is on the party relying thereon.Â  Morrow v. Dyches, 328 S.C. 522, 492 S.E.2d 420 (Ct. App. 1997); see also Matthews v. Dennis, 365 S.C. 245, 251, 616 S.E.2d 437, 440-41 (Ct. App. 2005) (stating the plaintiffs had the â€œburden of proof in establishing their right to a prescriptive easementâ€).Â  Thus, the special referee could reasonably have found that Jones did to meet her burden of proving her and her familyâ€™s use of the purported easement was continuous after 1959.
CONCLUSION 
There was evidence on which the special referee could base his finding that Jonesâ€™ predecessorâ€™s use of the purported easement did not begin until 1949 and ended, much less than twenty years later, in 1959.Â  Furthermore, the evidence also justified a finding that any use of the route that took place after 1959 was not sufficiently proven to be continuous and uninterrupted for the requisite time period. Â There was ample evidence to support the special refereeâ€™s finding that a prescriptive easement was not established.Â  Accordingly, and the special refereeâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

text:
THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Kay P. Curry, Appellant,
v.
Andrew Manigault d/b/a Manigault Estate Corporation, LLC,
Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
 Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-377
Heard November 9, 2006 â€“ Filed November 21, 2006

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Mark W. McKnight, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Morris A. Ellison, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: Kay Curry appeals the masterâ€™s order dismissing her foreclosure action against Andrew Manigault, d/b/a Manigault Estate Corporation, LLC, and denying her unjust enrichment claim.Â  We reverse and remand.Â  
I.
In 1988, Manigault and his two brothers, Robert Manigault (â€œRobertâ€) and John Manigault (â€œJohnâ€), formed Awendaw Creek Associates (â€œPartnershipâ€).Â  In 1993, the Partnership executed a promissory note (â€œNoteâ€) with South Carolina National Bank (â€œSNBâ€) for $446,987.Â  The Note was secured by a mortgage on 123 acres of Partnership property (â€œMortgageâ€), an assignment of contracts, and an assignment of leases, rents, and profits.Â  
In 1998, the Partnership and John Sanders (a financial backer) entered into a modification and extension agreement (â€œAgreementâ€) with SNBâ€™s successor in interest, Wachovia.Â  Under the Agreement, the Partnership and Sanders agreed to make quarterly payments of $17,092 to Wachovia until March 3, 2003, the Noteâ€™s maturity date.Â  Manigault, Robert, John, and Sanders all agreed to guarantee payments on the Note.Â  
In 2001, Curry negotiated with Robert and John about purchasing Partnership property.[1]Â  Robert and John agreed to sell their portion of the Partnership property to Curry, but Andrew Manigault refused to sell his portion to her.Â  Consequently, on October 25, 2001, Curry purchased Robertâ€™s and Johnâ€™s portion of the Partnership property, but not Andrew Manigaultâ€™s.Â  Because Wachovia would not release any of the Partnership property from the Mortgage unless the Note was paid in full, Curry agreed to purchase the Note and release Robert, John, and Sanders from the Mortgage, but not Manigault, who would continue to owe his balance of the Note.Â  
On November 16, 2001, Wachovia sent David Chard, the attorney handling the transaction between Curry, Robert, and John, a message indicating $346,783 would â€œpayoffâ€ the Note.Â  Three days later, Chard sent Wachovia a check for $346,783.Â  Chard also sent Wachovia a letter stating the check represented the â€œpayoffâ€ of the Note.Â  The letter further provided, â€œAs soon as possible after processing the enclosed check, please forward to us the original Note and Mortgage marked â€˜Paid and Satisfied In Fullâ€™ in order that we may have the same cancelled of record.â€Â  Although Curry unquestionably â€œpaid offâ€ the Note, she never received from Wachovia the original Note nor any correspondence related to the original Note.Â  
On March 4, 2002, Wachovia executed an â€œAssignment of Mortgage,â€ which by its terms assigned and transferred the Note and Mortgage to Curry.Â  Curry then sought to foreclose the mortgage on Manigaultâ€™s property, because Manigault did not pay Curry the amount she paid Wachovia for his share of the Noteâ€™s balance.Â  The matter was referred to the master.Â  At trial, Curry attempted to admit into evidence a copy of the Note, but Manigault objected based on a specific provision of the Uniform Commercial Code (â€œUCCâ€).Â  The master sustained Manigaultâ€™s objection.Â  Curry amended her pleadings, without objection, to include a claim for unjust enrichment.Â  In May 2005, the master dismissed Curryâ€™s foreclosure action and denied her claim for unjust enrichment.Â  Curry appealed.Â  
II.
An action to recover under an unjust enrichment claim sounds in equity.Â  Columbia Wholesale Co. v. Scudder May, 312 S.C. 259, 261, 440 S.E.2d 129, 130 (1994).Â  In an appeal from a masterâ€™s final judgment, this Court has the same standard of review as if the appeal had come from the circuit court without a jury.Â  Tiger, Inc. v. Fisher Agro, Inc., 301 S.C. 229, 237, 391 S.E.2d 538, 543 (1989).Â  â€œIn an action in equity tried by the judge alone, this Court can make findings of facts in accordance with our own view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â 
QHG of Lake City, Inc. v. McCutcheon, 360 S.C. 196, 202, 600 S.E.2d 105, 107 (Ct. App. 2004).
III.
Curry argues the master erred in denying her unjust enrichment claim.Â  We agree and find Curry is entitled to recover on her unjust enrichment claim.Â Â  
â€œUnjust enrichment is an equitable doctrine, akin to restitution, which permits the recovery of that amount the defendant has been unjustly enriched at the expense of the plaintiff.â€Â  Ellis v. Smith Grading & Paving, Inc., 294 S.C. 470, 473, 366 S.E.2d 12, 14 (Ct. App. 1988).Â  To recover on a theory of restitution, the plaintiff must show: â€œ(1) he conferred a nongratuitous benefit on the defendant; (2) the defendant realized some value from the benefit; and (3) it would be inequitable for the defendant to retain the benefit without paying the plaintiff its value.â€Â  Moore-Hudson Oldsmobile/GMC, Inc. v. Waterman, 298 S.C. 107, 109, 378 S.E.2d 279, 280 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  â€œWhether restitution should be required is a question to be decided on the facts of each case.â€Â  Niggel Assocs., Inc. v. Poloâ€™s of N. Myrtle Beach, Inc., 296 S.C. 530, 532, 374 S.E.2d 507, 509 (Ct. App. 1988). 
The master held that because Curry paid off the Note she has no equitable remedy against Manigault.Â  The master stated, â€œbefore [Curry] is entitled to claim restitution for unjust enrichment, she must prove that she acquired the right to payment from Defendant Manigault set forth in the Note.â€Â  This is an error of law.Â  The whole point of an unjust enrichment claim is to allow a plaintiff to recover for a benefit conferred to a defendant when that plaintiff lacked a contractual right against that defendant.Â  If Curry proved she â€œacquired the right to payment from Defendant Manigaultâ€â€”that is, if Curry established she had a contractual right to recover from Manigaultâ€”then she would not (and could not) resort to equity in the first instance.Â  See Van Robinson Ins. Agency, Inc. v. Harleysville Mut. Ins. Co., 272 S.C. 127, 128-29, 249 S.E.2d 744, 745 (1978) (holding that equity will not intervene if appellant has an adequate remedy at law).Â  Therefore, the master erred in concluding Curry could not seek equitable relief because she lacked a valid legal claim. 
Moreover, based on our view of the facts of this case, we are firmly persuaded Curry is entitled to restitution from Manigault.Â  First, there is no doubt Curry conferred a nongratuitous benefit to Manigault when she paid off Manigaultâ€™s portion of debt under the Note.Â  Second, because Manigault no longer owes Wachovia his portion of debt under the Note, Manigault realized value from Curryâ€™s payoff.Â  Third, it would be entirely inequitable to allow Manigault to retain this benefit without paying Curry for paying off his portion of the debt.Â  
Although Manigault claims he had no idea Curry intended to pay off his portion of the debt under the Note and recover it later, the evidence suggests otherwise.Â  The record indicates Manigault was well aware of the October 2001 transaction between Curry and the Partnership.Â  Chard, the attorney who handled the closing, testified that he discussed the terms of the October 2001 closing with Manigault before the transaction occurred.Â  Ed Perkins, a listing agent on the Partnership property, testified that Manigault attended meetings between Curry, John, Robert, and Sanders â€œquite a bit.â€Â  Ernest, Curryâ€™s agent, testified that he, Manigault, John, and Robert held a meeting where Manigault personally choose the parcel he wanted on a plat of the Partnership property Curry intended to purchase.Â  Ernest also testified that Manigault was at the October 2001 closing.Â  The evidence clearly establishes that Manigault knew not only about Curryâ€™s plan to purchase Partnership property (other than his share), but also her intent to pay off the Note and Mortgage.
IV.
We reverse and remand to the trial court to enter judgment against Manigault.Â  If required, the court shall conduct further proceedings to ascertain the precise amount due Curry.Â  The trial courtâ€™s order is 
 REVERSED AND REMANDED.[2]
HEARN, C.J., KITTREDGE, and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  More specifically, Curryâ€™s husband, Ernest, negotiated with Robert and John, but Ernest acted as Curryâ€™s agent throughout the transaction at issue in this case.
[2]Â  In light of this disposition, we need not address Curryâ€™s remaining issues.Â  Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One, 311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993).
