THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Michael Ziegenfus, Appellant,
v.
Fairfield Electric Cooperative, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Fairfield County
Â John C. Few, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-378
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed November 21, 2006

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
William P. Walker, Jr., of Lexington, for Appellant.
Pope D. Johnson, III, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this personal injury action, Michael Ziegenfus (Ziegenfus) appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment in favor of Fairfield Electric Cooperative, Inc. (Fairfield) on the basis of res judicata.Â  We affirm.[1]  
FACTS
In July 2001, Fairfield contracted out the work of its substation high-voltage electrical testing to Branyon Electrical Maintenance, Inc. (Branyon). Â An explosion ensued while Ziegenfus, an employee of Branyon, was testing an energized piece of substation equipment owned by Fairfield.Â  As a result of the explosion, Ziegenfus was severely injured, suffering permanent scarring, disfigurement, and loss of function from third degree burns over forty-five percent of his body.
On August 1, 2001, Ziegenfus filed a Form 50 seeking workersâ€™ compensation benefits for his injuries as an employee of Branyon.Â  At the time of the injuries, Branyon was operating under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act; its compensation carrier was Monumental General Casualty Company (Monumental).Â  On December 18, 2001, Ziegenfus filed an Amended Form 50 joining Fairfield and its compensation carrier, Federated Rural Electric Insurance Company (Federated), to the proceeding on the grounds that Branyon, a subcontractor of Fairfield, may have no insurance coverage for the claim.Â  
On June 18, 2002, the Single Commissioner of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission held a hearing to determine which employers and carriers were liable for compensation to Ziegenfus.Â  The Single Commissioner found that Branyon, and Monumental as its carrier, were liable for the injuries sustained by Ziegenfus.Â  The Single Commissioner further found that in the event Monumental appealed the order and it was determined that Monumental in fact had no coverage, Fairfield would then be liable to Ziegenfus as an â€œupstream employer.[2]â€Â  Accordingly, the Single Commissioner concluded that Fairfieldâ€™s carrier, Federated, would be liable for compensation to Ziegenfus.Â  The Appellate Panel affirmed the decision of the Single Commissioner.Â  The findings of fact and conclusions of law from the Single Commissionerâ€™s order were incorporated by reference into the decision of the Appellate Panel. 
On March 1, 2004, Ziegenfus filed a civil action against Fairfield alleging strict liability and negligence for failing to de-energize the equipment which it owned and on which Ziegenfus was working on the date he sustained the electrical injuries.Â  On June 4, 2004, Fairfield moved for summary judgment on the ground that the Commissionâ€™s order had established, as res judicata, that Fairfield was a statutory employer of Ziegenfus and, therefore, his exclusive remedy was under the South Carolina Workerâ€™s Compensation Act.Â  
On April 21, 2005, the circuit court granted summary judgment in favor of Fairfield, finding that under the doctrine of res judicata, because Ziegenfus was found to be a statutory employee of Fairfieldâ€™s in the workersâ€™ compensation proceeding, Ziegenfus could not relitigate the issue in a civil action.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment, the appellate court is instructed to apply the same standard that governs the circuit court under Rule 56(c) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure; summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact, and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  To determine whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences, which can reasonably be drawn therefrom, must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Faile v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Juvenile Justice, 350 S.C. 315, 324, 566 S.E.2d 536, 540 (2002).Â  â€œIf triable issues exist, those issues must go to the jury.â€Â  Young v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 333 S.C. 714, 717, 511 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 1999).
On the other hand, â€œsummary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.â€Â  Vermeer Carolinaâ€™s, Inc. v. Wood/Chuck Chipper Corp., 336 S.C. 53, 59, 518 S.E.2d 301, 305 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  All ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed most strongly against the moving party.Â  Bayle v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 344 S.C. 115, 120, 542 S.E.2d 736, 738 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Summary judgment should be denied even when there is no dispute as to evidentiary facts, but only as to the conclusions or inferences to be drawn from them.Â Â  Hall v. Fedor, 349 S.C. 169, 173-74, 561 S.E.2d 654, 656 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Summary judgment is a drastic remedy; it should therefore be cautiously invoked to prevent the improper deprivation of a trial of the disputed factual issues.Â Â  Lanham v. Blue Cross & Blue Shield, 349 S.C. 356, 363, 563 S.E.2d 331, 334 (2002).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Application of the Doctrine of Res Judicata 
Ziegenfus contends the circuit court erred in granting Fairfieldâ€™s motion
for summary judgment on the basis of res judicata.Â  Ziegenfus specifically contends the Commissionâ€™s findings regarding Fairfield were unnecessary and immaterial to the decision awarding workerâ€™s compensation benefits to Ziegenfus, and therefore res judicata did not apply.Â  Ziegenfus further contends that Fairfield was not a primary party, but rather an alternate party in the compensation hearing, and the liability of Fairfield was not a matter put in issue by Ziegenfus.Â  We disagree. 
The Supreme Court of South Carolina has held that res judicata applies if the following elements are met: (1) the identities of the parties are the same as in the prior litigation; (2) the subject matter or cause of action is the same as in the prior litigation; and (3) there was a prior adjudication of the issue by a court of competent jurisdiction.Â  Johnson v. Greenwood Mills, Inc., 317 S.C. 248, 250-251, 452 S.E.2d 832, 833 (1994); Griggs v. Griggs, 214 S.C. 177, 51 S.E.2d 622, 627 (1949).Â  

In the application of the doctrine of res judicata, if it is doubtful whether a second action is for the same cause of action as the first, the test generally applied is to consider the identity of facts essential to their maintenance, or whether the same evidence would sustain both.Â  If the same facts or evidence would sustain both, the two actions are considered the same within the rule that the judgment in the former is a bar to the subsequent action.Â  Moreover, before the doctrine of res judicata is applied in such cases, it should appear that the precise question involved in the subsequent action was determined in the former action.

Griggs, 214 S.C. at 177, 51 S.E.2d at 626.Â  
As to the first element of res judicata, Ziegenfus filed an Amended Form 50, naming Fairfield as a party in the workerâ€™s compensation proceeding.Â  Likewise, the record shows that Ziegenfus also named Fairfield as a party defendant in the civil action.Â  Ziegenfus remained the claimant/plaintiff party in both actions.Â  Since the identities of the parties were the same in the prior compensation proceeding as in the instant civil action, the first element of res judicata has been adequately met.
As to the second element of res judicata, Ziegenfus directly presented to the Commission the determination of whether Fairfield had any liability in the matter.Â  Further, Ziegenfus filed an Amended Form 50, specifically joining Fairfield as a party to the compensation proceeding.Â  Therefore, despite Ziegenfusâ€™ contention otherwise, he put the issue of Fairfieldâ€™s liability in the matter by seeking the Commissionâ€™s determination of Fairfieldâ€™s liability based on its status as his statutory employer.Â  Likewise, in the instant civil action, Ziegenfus alleged Fairfieldâ€™s liability for the injuries he sustained as a statutory employee of Fairfield, while testing equipment owned by Fairfield.Â  Therefore, as required by Griggs, the subject matter is the same in both actions.
Moreover, under the Griggs test, the Commission found that Fairfield contracted with Branyon to perform work integral to the operation of its business, and Ziegenfus, as an employee of Branyon, was injured during the work.Â  Likewise, in the civil action, Ziegenfus asserted Fairfield â€œsecured Branyon, an independent contractor together with its employees,â€ including Ziegenfus, to perform high-voltage testing of its substation.Â  Here, evidence in both the workersâ€™ compensation proceeding and the instant action show that Fairfield was a statutory employer of Ziegenfus.Â  Under the Griggs test, because the same facts or evidence are relevant to the determination of the claims raised in each action, the two actions are considered the same for res judicata purposes. 
As to the final element of res judicata, the Commission found Fairfield would be liable to Ziegenfus as an upstream employer in the event Monumental had no coverage.Â  This finding was not immaterial because Ziegenfus sought that determination in his Amended Form 50.Â  
Based on the above, we find all three elements of res judicata were met in this matter.Â  The circuit court, therefore, did not err in applying the doctrine of res judicata based on the Commissionâ€™s adjudication that Fairfield was a statutory employer of Ziegenfus.
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we find Ziegenfus failed to present facts sufficient to raise a genuine issue of any material fact as to whether the doctrine of res judicata applied in this matter. The decision of the circuit court is accordingly
 AFFIRMED.
 HUFF, SHORT, JJ. and CURETON, AJ., concur.

[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The Single Commissionerâ€™s reference to Fairfield as an â€œupstream employerâ€ of Ziegenfusâ€™ is synonymous to Fairfieldâ€™s status as a â€œstatutory employerâ€ of Ziegenfusâ€™. Â

title: Phillips v. Any Lengths Recovery
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
Wanda Phillips, Respondent,
v.
Martin Bayless, Bryson Folks, Any Lengths Recovery, Inc., d/b/a Any Lengths Recovery Community and Paradise Properties, Inc.,
Defendants,
Of which Any Lengths Recovery, Inc., d/b/a Any Lengths Recovery Community is
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Sumter County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-379
Submitted October 1, 2006 â€“ Filed November 21, 2006

AFFIRMED 


  
    
      
Tressa T.H. Hayes, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Amanda Graham Steinmeyer, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  This is an appeal by Appellant Any Lengths Recovery, Inc. (Any Lengths) in an action where Respondent Wanda Phillips (Phillips) alleged premises liability and negligence against Any Lengths.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of Phillips based on Any Lengthsâ€™ failure to respond to Phillipsâ€™ request for admissions.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
In August of 2000, Phillips was a resident at Any Lengths Recovery, Inc., a rehabilitation treatment facility.Â  On August 13, 2000,Â  while playing a game of volleyball at the facility, Phillips was suddenly knocked to the ground by two dogs.[2]Â  As a result, she suffered injuries requiring reconstructive surgery on her knee. She continues on pain medications for symptoms resulting from the injuries.Â  Phillips alleged the common area where her injuries were sustained were under the control of Any Lengths.Â  
On July 7, 2004, Phillips sued Any Lengths alleging both premises liability and negligence.Â  In its Answer, Any Lengths denied liability for Phillipsâ€™ injuries.Â  On January 28, 2004, Phillips sent her first interrogatories and request to produce to Any Lengths.Â  On March 4, 2004, Phillips sent Any Lengths a letter asking for a response to her discovery requests.Â  Five months later, Phillips still had not received any response from Any Lengths.Â  Phillips, then, sent a second letter to Any Lengths in August of 2004 requesting Any Lengths to respond to her discovery requests, and threatening to file a motion to compel. Â Â Because Any Lengthsâ€™ failed to respond, Phillips filed a motion to compel on August 18, 2004.Â  Notice of the hearing on the motion to compel was given to all parties.Â  In the meantime, Phillips served Any Lengths with a second interrogatory and request for production on September 1, 2004, and a third interrogatory and request for production on September 22, 2004, to which Any Lengths also did not respond.Â  
On January 4, 2005, the trial court heard Phillipsâ€™ motion to compel and noted that Any Lengths failed to appear at the hearing.Â  The trial court granted Phillipsâ€™ motion to compel and ordered Any Lengths to â€œcomply with all outstanding discovery requested by Plaintiff without any objections whatsoever within ten days after entry of this order.â€Â  The trial court further ordered that failure to comply with the order would result in â€œall appropriate remedies and sanctions available.â€Â  A cover letter from the Clerk of Court states that on February 4, 2005, the trial courtâ€™s order to compel was mailed to counsel for Any Lengths.Â  Nevertheless, on January 10, 2005, Phillips served a second copy of the trial courtâ€™s ruling on Any Lengths by way of facsimile and regular mail.Â  Any Lengths did not respond to the discovery order within ten days as ordered.Â  
On January 27, 2005, Phillips mailed a request for admissions to Any Lengthsâ€™ counsel.Â  Any Lengths, however, did not respond to Phillipsâ€™ request with either written responses or objection to the request.Â  Counsel for Any Lengths claimed he did not receive the request.Â  However, the Record on Appeal shows a certificate of service was attached to the copy of the request for admissions mailed to Any Lengths.Â  On March 7, 2005, Phillips moved for summary judgment based upon Any Lengthsâ€™ failure to respond to discovery, including its failure to comply with the courtâ€™s order, and a failure to respond to the request for admissions.Â  Any Lengths was served with notice of the motion for summary judgment on the same date.Â  On April 4, 2005, the trial court granted the motion for summary judgment as to liability against Any Lengths for failure to respond to the request for admissions, which under Rule 36 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, was deemed admitted.Â  
On April 5, 2005, Any Lengths moved for reconsideration of the summary judgment order, which the court subsequently denied.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing the grant of a summary judgment motion, the appellate court applies the same standard that governs the trial court under Rule 56(c) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure; summary judgment is proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact, and the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 493, 567 S.E.2d 857, 860 (2002).Â  In determining whether any triable issue of fact exists, the evidence and all inferences, which can reasonably be drawn therefrom, must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Faile v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Juvenile Justice, 350 S.C. 315, 324, 566 S.E.2d 536, 540 (2002).Â  â€œIf triable issues exist, those issues must go to the jury.â€Â  Young v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 333 S.C. 714, 717, 511 S.E.2d 413, 415 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œSummary judgment is not appropriate where further inquiry into the facts of the case is desirable to clarify the application of the law.â€Â  Vermeer Carolinaâ€™s Inc. v. Wool/Chuck Chipper Corp., 336 S.C. 53, 59, 518 S.E.2d 301, 305 (Ct. App. 1999).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Â As a primary matter, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment against Any Lengths based on Rule 220(c) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  Rule 220(c), SCRCP states: â€œThe appellate court may affirm any ruling, order, or judgment upon any ground(s) appearing in the Record on Appeal.â€ The Record on Appeal indicates counsel for Any Lengths has repeatedly failed to respond to Phillipsâ€™ discovery requests since the commencement of this litigation, which had been nearly two years on the date of the hearing on the motion for summary judgment on April 4, 2005. 
Any Lengths failed to respond to four sets of interrogatories and requests to produce.Â  Any Lengths also failed to respond to Phillipsâ€™ request for admissions or appear at the hearing on motion to compel.Â  Any Lengths even failed to respond to a court order compelling its response to outstanding discovery within ten days of entry of the order.Â  These omissions occurred despite Any Lengthsâ€™ admission to receipt of such documents as: (1) two letters from Phillips requesting production; (2) notice of Phillipsâ€™ motion to compel; (3) a copy of the courtâ€™s order regarding the motion to compel; (4) Phillipsâ€™ fourth request for production; and (5) notice of Phillipsâ€™ motion for summary judgment.Â  Under these circumstances, and in view of the history of Any Lengthsâ€™ failure to respond to discovery even to the point of disregarding a court order, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment.
I.  Non-receipt of Request for Admissions
As to Any Lengthsâ€™ contention that the trial court erred in deeming Phillipsâ€™ request to admit admitted in the face of Any Lengthsâ€™ claim it did not receive notice of the request until it received Phillipsâ€™ summary judgment motion, we find no error. 
South Carolina Rule of Civil Procedure 5(b)(1) provides that â€œservice upon the attorney or upon a party shall be made by delivering a copy to the attorney or party or by mailing it to him at his last known address or, if no address is known, by leaving it with the clerk of court.â€Â  Service by mail is therefore complete upon mailing of all pleadings following service of the original summons and complaint.Â  Rule 5(b)(1), SCRCP.Â  
Here, the Record on Appeal indicates Phillips met the burden of showing that notice was actually mailed by presenting a valid certificate of service dated January 27, 2005.Â  Therefore, the record supports the trial courtâ€™s acceptance of Phillipsâ€™ certification that the request for admissions had been mailed, in spite of Any Lengthsâ€™ claim[3] of non-receipt of the request. 
Further, under Rule 36(a) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, â€œall matters contained in a request for admissions are admitted unless, within 30 days after service of the request, or within such shorter or longer time as the court may allow, the party serves answers or objects to the matter.â€Â  Hinson-Barr, Inc. v. Pinckard, 292 S.C. 267, 269-70, 356 S.E.2d 115, 116 (1987). â€œFailure to respond to a request for admissions deems the request admitted.â€Â  Rule 36(a), SCRCP; Hatchell v. Jackson, 290 S.C. 256, 258, 349 S.E.2d 407, 408 (Ct. App. 1986).Â  Â 
II.  Time to Respond Not Yet Expired 
We also reject Any Lengths contention the trial court erred in deeming Phillipsâ€™ request for admissions admitted and granting summary judgment against Any Lengths because Phillipsâ€™ notice of summary judgment motion constituted subsequent service of the request for admissions.Â  Thus, the time to respond to the request had not expired when the court deemed the request admitted.Â  In view of our holding that there was no error on the part of the trial court in accepting Phillipsâ€™ certification of service of the request for admissions, we hold this argument to be manifestly without merit and dispose of it pursuant to Rule 220(c), SCRCP.
III.  Bright-Line Test
Finally, as to Any Lengthsâ€™ contention the trial court erred in deeming Phillipsâ€™ request for admissions admitted and the application of a bright line test, we find no error.
Relying on Collins v. White, 363 S.C. 546, 611 S.E.2d 262 (Ct. App. 2005), Any Lengths argues that instead of applying a bright line test, the trial court should have exercised its discretion and refused to deem the request admitted when the admissions arose solely from the failure to make a timely response.Â  However, Any Lengthsâ€™ reliance on Collins is misplaced and demonstrates a misunderstanding of the procedural facts upon which the court in Collins determined judicial discretion was appropriate in refusing to deem the request admitted.Â  
In Collins, the court refused to deem the unanswered request admitted because not only did the party to whom the response was requested fail to respond in a timely manner, but the requesting party knowingly sent the requests to the wrong address with the understanding that no attorney was present or practiced at that address. 363 S.C. at 553, 611 S.E.2d at 265.Â  The record does not indicate that such a deceptive act occurred in the present case.Â  Further, in Collins, the court permitted the party to whom the response was requested to file a late response to the request pursuant to the partyâ€™s motion to file a late answer to the request. Id.Â  In the present case,Â  Any Lengths did not request additional time to respond to the request, not even between the date Any Lengths claimed to have learned of the request by way of the notice of motion for summary judgment on March 7, 2005, and the time of the hearing on the motion for reconsideration on April 6, 2005.Â  
Under Rule 36(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure, any matter admitted under Rule 36(a) is â€œconclusively established unless the court on motion permits withdrawal or amendment of the admission.â€ Scott v. Greenville Housing Auth., 353 S.C. 639, 645, 579 S.E.2d 151, 154 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  Once a party moves for withdrawal or amendment of the admission, the court applies a test to determine: (1) whether the presentation of the merits of the action will be subserved by the withdrawal or amendment; and (2) whether the party who obtained the admission can prove to the court that the withdrawal or amendment will prejudice him in maintaining his action or defense on the merits.Â  Rule 36(b), SCRCP; Â Baughman v. American Tel. & Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101, 109-110, 410 S.E.2d 537, 542 (1991). However, if the party seeking to amend or withdraw the admission does not move for withdrawal or amendment, the court will not need to apply the test for withdrawal or amendment and will deem the request admitted.Â  Hinson-Barr, Inc. v. Pinckard, 292 S.C. 267, 270, 356 S.E.2d 115, 117 (1987) (finding that because buyer made no motion to withdraw or amend his admissions, they were deemed admitted).
Any Lengths claims it requested permission at the summary judgment hearing to respond to discovery. However, as we read the record, Any Lengthsâ€™ counselâ€™s request at the summary judgment hearing concerned the motion to produce, not the request for admissions.Â  
We find the trial court appropriately applied the bright line test given the lack of Any Lengthsâ€™ attempts to move to file a late response to the request for admissions.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court did not err in deeming Phillipsâ€™ request for admissions admitted and granting summary judgment against Any Lengths based upon its application of the bright line test.
CONCLUSION
Â For the foregoing reasons, the trial court properly deemed the
request for admissions admitted and granted summary judgment against Any Lengths on the grounds of Any Lengthsâ€™ failure to respond to the request under Rule 36 of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure and its failure to respond to discovery in general.Â  Â Â Â Â Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment to Phillips is
AFFIRMED.
HUFF, SHORT, JJ., and CURETON, AJ., concur. 

[1]Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2] The two dogs were owned by Defendants Martin Bayless and Bryson Folks, both of whom are not parties to this appeal.Â  
[3] Any Lengthsâ€™ attorneyâ€™s claim of non-receipt is based on the fact that the request for admissions could not be found in his file. The fact that the request could not be found in the file is not proof that it was not received by his office. The mailing of the request, along with a valid certificate of service, gave rise to a rebuttable presumption of receipt.Â  Weir v. Citicorp Natâ€™l Serv., Inc., 312 S.C. 511, 513, 435 S.E.2d 864, 868 (1993) (finding a rebuttable presumption regarding receipt is established upon the evidence of mailing a properly addressed document).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Mark A. and Karyn M. Brinkley, Respondents,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Gregory K. Martin, ASL, Inc., a/k/a All Saints Landing, a Corporation; Wayne Hucks, Danny T. and Deborah Carroll, and Ron Teague, Defendants,
        Of Whom Gregory K. Martin is the Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Paula H. Thomas, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-380
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed November 22, 2006

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Warren C. Powell, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.Â  
        Francis T. Draine, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Mark A. and Karyn M. Brinkley filed this negligence and legal malpractice action arising from a real estate transaction against Gregory K. Martin, ASL, Inc., a/k/a All Saints Landing, a Corporation, Wayne Hucks, Danny T. and Deborah Carroll, and Ron Teague.Â The circuit court granted the Brinkleysâ€™ motion to transfer the case to the jury docket.Â  Gregory Martin appeals.Â  We reverse.[1] 
FACTS
With the commencement of this action, the Brinkleys demanded a jury trial.Â  The circuit court referred the matter to the master in equity with finality by order filed September 24, 2001.Â  No appeal was taken from this order.Â  Shortly thereafter, the master ruled on one issue in the case.Â  Other issues remained undecided.Â  Approximately two and a half years later, the Brinkleys moved to transfer the case to the active jury trial roster on the sole ground the reference to the master was a mistake.Â  After ruling on another pending issue in the case, the master wrote the chief administrative judge requesting recusal for the remainder of the case. Â Judge Paula Thomas responded on March 24, 2004, recusing the master and informing the parties they must agree on a special referee within five days â€œor the case will be put on the Court roster.â€ Â 
Judge Cottingham denied the Brinkleysâ€™ motion to transfer the matter to the jury roster by order dated May 3, 2004, finding the order of reference affected the mode of trial and should have been immediately appealed.[2]Â  Judge Cottingham also found the motion, based on the ground of â€œmistake,â€ was not made within the one year limitation of Rule 60(b), SCRCP. Â The Brinkleys did not appeal this order.Â  
In February of 2005, the Brinkleys moved for change of venue from Horry County to Florence County, and complained about the delay in the case being set for trial on the Horry County jury roster.Â  By order filed September 12, 2005, Judge Thomas concluded the â€œeffect of [the masterâ€™s] recusal was that jurisdiction of the case should be referredâ€ to the special referee.Â  Judge Thomas accordingly referred the action to the special referee to enter final judgment.Â  On September 13, 2005, the Brinkleys forwarded a chronology of events and supporting documentation to Judge Thomas.Â  In response, Judge Thomas declared the September 24, 2001 order of reference to the master â€œnull and voidâ€ and transferred the case to the jury docket.Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
 Martin argues Judge Thomas erred in voiding the September 24, 2001 order of reference and effectively reversing Judge Cottinghamâ€™s May 3, 2004 order denying the Brinkleysâ€™ motion to transfer the case to the jury roster.Â  We agree.
In their motion to transfer the case to the jury roster, the Brinkleys relied on â€œmistakeâ€ as the ground for setting aside the original order of reference.Â  A motion to set aside an order on the ground of mistake is governed by Rule 60(b)(1) of the South Carolina Rules of Civil Procedure.Â  Rule 60(b) provides:
    
      On motion and upon such terms as are just, the court may relieve a party or his legal representative from a final judgment, order, or proceeding for the following reasons:
       (1) Â mistake, inadvertence, surprise, or excusable neglect;
      * * *
      The motion shall be made within a reasonable time, and for reasons (1), (2), and (3) not more than one year after the judgment, order or proceeding was entered or taken.
    
Rule 60(b), SCRCP. Â The one year limit for motions pursuant to Rule 60(b)(1)-(3) is an absolute time limit.Â  Coleman v. Dunlap, 306 S.C. 491, 495, 413 S.E.2d 15, 17 (1992).Â  The Brinkleysâ€™ motion to transfer the case to the jury roster is dated March 5, 2004, more than two years after the filing of the September 24, 2001 order of reference.Â  We find Judge Cottingham correctly concluded the motion to transfer the case to the jury calendar, based on a mistake in the order of reference, was not timely filed pursuant to Rule 60(b)(1).Â  
    Furthermore, the Brinkleysâ€™ failure to appeal either the order of reference or Judge Cottinghamâ€™s order finally determines the mode of trial issue.Â  A party waives its right to a jury trial by failing to immediately appeal an order denying a motion for a jury trial.Â  Lester v. Dawson, 327 S.C. 263, 265, 491 S.E.2d 240, 241 (1997).Â  See also Edwards v. Timmons, 297 S.C. 314, 316, 377 S.E.2d 97, 97 (1988) (holding that the trial courtâ€™s unappealed order of reference to a master in equity became the law of the case); Creed v. Stokes, 285 S.C. 542, 542-43, 331 S.E.2d 351, 352 (1985) (finding the appellant waived his objection to the order of reference by not immediately appealing the order).
    Because the order of reference was not appealed and Judge Cottinghamâ€™s order appropriately applied Rule 60(b)(1) and was likewise not appealed, the mode of trial issue was finally determined prior to the Brinkleysâ€™ submission of a chronology and documentation to Judge Thomas.Â  Accordingly, the order voiding the order of reference and effectively reversing the order denying the Brinkleysâ€™ motion to transfer the case to the jury roster is reversed.Â  See also Medlock v. Love Shop, Ltd., 286 S.C. 486, 487, 334 S.E.2d 528, 529 (Ct. App. 1985) (holding that one circuit judge does not have the power to review, modify, affirm, or reverse findings of another circuit court judge).
    REVERSED.
    GOOLSBY, STILWELL, and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1]Â We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â This court may not consider any alleged error in the trial courtâ€™s failure to continue the matter as the Brinkleys did not appeal the issue.Â  See Town of Mt. Pleasant v. Jones, 335 S.C. 295, 298-99, 516 S.E.2d 468, 470 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding an unappealed ruling becomes the law of the case, and the appellate court must assume the ruling was correct).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        South Carolina Department of Social Services, Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Valerie Vanessa Mathis B.; Ronald B.; Hector Manuel L., Jr., DOB: 02/27/91; and Veronica Lee B., DOB:Â  02/01/95; Defendants,
        of whom Valerie Vanessa Mathis B. is Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
Â Jocelyn B. Cate, Family Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2006-UP-382
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed November 27, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Diedra W. Hightower, of Charleston, for Appellant.
        Thomas P. Stoney, II, of Moncks Corner, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Valerie Vanessa Mathis B.[1] (Mother) appeals the family courtâ€™s order terminating her parental rights to her two minor children.Â  We affirm.[2]
FACTS/PROCEDUREAL HISTORY
Mother is the parent of three children, each of whom has a different father.Â  Her oldest child is emancipated and not part of this termination of parental rights (TPR) action. Â Mother gave birth to Hector Manuel L., Jr. (Hector) on February 27, 1991.Â  Hectorâ€™s father is deceased and not part of this TPR action.Â  Motherâ€™s youngest child is Veronica Lee B. (Veronica), who was born on February 1, 1995, to Ronald B. (Father).Â  
DSS took the children into emergency protective custody on January 10, 2002, on allegations of educational neglect and threat of harm of physical neglect.[3]Â  At the time, Mother was living in a hotel purportedly after leaving the family residence due to domestic violence, and the children did not attend school. Â On the night before the children were removed, Mother had used crack cocaine in bed with her paramour while the children slept just a few feet away on a couch.Â  
On February 11, 2002, Mother consented to begin a treatment plan.Â  Among other things, the treatment plan required that within six months she: Â financially support the children; provide a safe and nurturing home free from abuse and neglect; sign specific releases; submit to random drug screenings; and engage in recommended drug counseling, alcohol counseling, and family therapy.Â  Mother ultimately was discharged from four substance abuse programs for failing to attend scheduled appointments or testing positive for cocaine or crack cocaine. 
DSS ultimately initiated the present action on October 1, 2003.Â  A final hearing was originally scheduled for January 24, 2005, but was continued so Mother could have a final opportunity to demonstrate compliance with the treatment plan.Â  Based on what essentially amounted to the partiesâ€™ reiteration of Motherâ€™s previous treatment plan, in February 2005 Mother agreed to: Â obtain proper housing by March 1, 2005; sign releases for her treatment providers; submit to hair follicle testing by February 14, 2005; undergo random urine testing for drugs; obtain written updates from her treatment providers; provide proof she receives a steady income; and clear outstanding warrants for her arrest by March 1, 2005.Â  Mother admittedly failed to achieve any of these tasks except for clearing her outstanding arrest warrants. 
In an attempt to resolve her outstanding arrest warrants, Mother was incarcerated on February 15, 2005, for charges of breach of trust, forgery, passing fraudulent checks to her employer, and probation violation.Â  Her anticipated release date was July 1, 2005.Â  
The merits hearing that began in January 2005 resumed on June 6, 2005.Â  The family court issued a written order on July 12, 2005, in which it found Mother had failed to demonstrate compliance with her treatment plan, among other things.Â  The court terminated Motherâ€™s parental rights to her minor children pursuant to the following statutory grounds:Â  (1) failing to remedy the conditions that led to the childrenâ€™s removal; (2) willfully failing to support her minor children; and (3) because her minor children had been in foster care for fifteen of the preceding twenty-two months.Â  After finding statutory grounds for termination, the family court also determined that TPR was in the childrenâ€™s best interests.[4] Â This appeal followed.
SCOPE OF REVIEW
Under South Carolinaâ€™s TPR statute, â€œ[t]he family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more of the [listed] grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005).Â  Grounds for TPR must be proved by clear and convincing evidence.  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 296, 513 S.E.2d 358, 366 (1999).Â  On appeal, this court may review the record and make its own determination whether the grounds for termination are supported by clear and convincing evidence.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 293, 547 S.E.2d 506, 509 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  Despite this broad scope of review, however, we should not necessarily disregard the findings of the family court because the family court is in a better position to evaluate the credibility of the witnesses and assign weight to their testimony.Â  Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996).
DISCUSSION
Mother does not dispute that her minor children were in foster care for at least fifteen of the twenty-two months preceding the TPR hearing.[5]Â  Instead, she contends the family court erred in terminating her parental rights solely on the statutory basis that the children had been in foster care under DSS custody for at least fifteen of the previous months.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(8) (Supp. 2005) (providing a ground for termination where a child has been in DSS custody for fifteen of the preceding twenty-two months).Â  Specifically, Mother claims such a termination â€œdoes not comport with due process or fundamental fairness under federal constitution.â€ Â Â Â Â  
The record, however, contains no indication that this issue was ever raised to or ruled upon by the family court.Â  Thus, the issue is not preserved for appellate review.Â  See Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Jackson, 368 S.C. 87, 104-05, 627 S.E.2d 765, 775 (Ct. App. 2006) (finding Fatherâ€™s claim that termination of parental rights violated his right to due process was not preserved for appellate review since this issue was not raised to or ruled upon by the trial court); Grant v. S.C. Coastal Council, 319 S.C. 348, 356, 461 S.E.2d 388, 392 (1995) (holding a constitutional due process claim raised for first time on appeal was not preserved); In re Care & Treatment of Corley, 365 S.C. 252, 258, 616 S.E.2d 441, 444 (Ct. App. 2005) (â€œConstitutional issues, like most others, must be raised to and ruled on by the trial court to be preserved for appeal.â€). Â Â 
Because we find at least one statutory ground for TPR has been met, the only issue remaining for us to consider is whether termination is in the childrenâ€™s best interests. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005) (providing family court may terminate parental rights if it finds at least one of the statutory grounds for termination has been met and that termination is in the best interests of the child); S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Sims, 359 S.C. 601, 608, 598 S.E.2d 303, 307 (Ct. App. 2004) (â€œA finding pursuant to section 20-7-1572(8) alone is sufficient to support a termination of parental rights.â€); see also Charleston County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. King, 369 S.C. 96, ____, 631 S.E.2d 239, 241 (2006) (declining to address merits of arguments against additional TPR grounds where at least one TPR ground is undisputedly proven).[6] Â 
Based on our review of the record, we find there is clear and convincing evidence that the termination of Motherâ€™s parental rights was in the best interests of the children.Â  Testimony from the childrenâ€™s guardian ad litem indicates their best interests were served by terminating Motherâ€™s parental rights.Â  She testified she had been the childrenâ€™s guardian for over three years and during that time Mother had been difficult to communicate with and was uncooperative and difficult.Â  She said the children were doing much better, and were living in a loving, stable, and secure home.Â  In particular, she noted that Veronica had initially been belligerent and would â€œact out,â€ but had since made a â€œ100 percent turnaround.â€ Â The guardian ad litem expressly testified that terminating Motherâ€™s parental rights was in the childrenâ€™s best interests.Â  
Based on the foregoing, the TPR order of the family court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]Â In order to protect the identities of the parties, we refer to them only by their first names and the last initial.
[2] Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[3] DSS had previously been involved with the family in 1998.Â  At that time, Mother fled to Florida to avoid having the children taken into emergency protective custody.Â  Mother eventually fled the State of Florida and returned to South Carolina after Florida authorities sought to take the children into protective custody following reports that Mother had left the children at home unsupervised for an entire day.Â  
[4]Â Section 20-7-1572(2), (4), and (8) of the South Carolina Code provides the family court may order the termination of parental rights upon a finding of one or more of the following grounds and a finding that termination is in the best interest of the child:
(2) The child has been removed from the parent pursuant to Section 20-7-610 or Section 20-7-736, has been out of the home for a period of six months following the adoption of a placement plan by court order or by agreement between the department and the parent, and the parent has not remedied the conditions which caused the removal;
. . .
(4) The child has lived outside the home of either parent for a period of six months, and during that time the parent has willfully failed to support the child. Â Failure to support means that the parent has failed to make a material contribution to the childâ€™s care. Â A material contribution consists of either financial contributions according to the parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other necessities for the care of the child according to the parentâ€™s means. Â The court may consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or not the parent has willfully failed to support the child, including requests for support by the custodian and the ability of the parent to provide support;
. . . 
8) The child has been in foster care under the responsibility of the State for fifteen of the most recent twenty-two months.
S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572 (Supp. 2005).
[5]Â  At the time of the hearing in June 2005, the children had been in foster care for approximately forty months or three and one-half years.Â  
[6]Â  In light of our affirmance on this ground, we find it unnecessary to address Motherâ€™s remaining issues in which she challenges the family courtâ€™s findings regarding the following statutory grounds for termination:Â  (1)Â  she willfully failed to comply with the February 2005 treatment plan; (2) there was clear and convincing evidence that she willfully refused to remedy the conditions that caused the removal of her children; and (3) she willfully failed to make material contributions for the care of her children while in the custody of DSS. Â See Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Phillips, 365 S.C. 572, 577, 618 S.E.2d 922, 924 (Ct. App. 2005) (declining to address in TPR action family courtâ€™s additional finding concerning Motherâ€™s failure to support child where appellate court affirmed finding that Mother failed to adequately remedy the conditions which caused the childâ€™s removal).
 Additionally, Mother argues the family court improperly shifted to her the burden â€œto present clear and convincing evidence to disprove the charges lodged by DSS.â€Â Â  To support her argument, Mother only makes reference to statements by DSS and the childrenâ€™s guardian ad litem indicating Mother failed to demonstrate compliance with her treatment plan.Â  However, Mother admitted at trial that the burden was on her to demonstrate she completed her treatment plan. Â Because Mother conceded this issue at trial, she may not raise it on appeal.Â  See Condor, Inc. v. Bd. of Zoning Appeals, 328 S.C. 173, 178, 493 S.E.2d 342, 344 (1997) (holding an issue conceded in trial court cannot be argued on appeal).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Timothy Murray, Claimant/Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Avondale Mills, Employer/Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken County
Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-383
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed November 27, 2006

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        F. Earl Ellis, Jr., of Columbia; for Appellant.
        Ernest Caskey Trammell, of Anderson; for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this workerâ€™s compensation case, Avondale Mills, Inc. (Employer), appeals the circuit courtâ€™s order affirming the decision of the Appellate Panel of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (Full Commission) awarding benefits to Timothy Murray for ruptured cervical discs.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
On April 20, 2003, Murray, a twenty-three-year employee of Avondale Mills, sustained an injury to his neck while working as a slotter in the textile mill.Â  As a slotter, Murray monitored three frame machines through which cotton and polyester are fed.Â  This job required Murray to bend, stoop, squat, climb, push, pull, reach, twist and turn in order to keep the machines operational.Â  As part of this process, Murray was often required to â€œfix an endâ€ by walking around the frame, stepping up on it, bending over and then putting the end up.Â  On the day of the injury, Murray was fixing the end on frame number eight when he noticed that frame number nine was getting ready to stop.Â  Murray then moved from frame number eight to frame number nine.Â  As Murray stood up, turned and twisted to his right while going down the two steps to tend to frame number nine, he felt pain in his neck and right arm.
Murray immediately reported the injury to his supervisor.Â  He then completed the remaining three hours of his shift.Â  Because the pain in his neck and right arm persisted, Murray sought treatment two days later from his family doctor.Â  Shortly thereafter, an MRI revealed that Murray had herniated C5-6 and C6-7 discs.Â  After physical therapy did not alleviate Murrayâ€™s pain, Dr. Oetting, a neurosurgeon, performed surgery on Murray for an â€œanterior cervical diskectomy and fusion with allograft and Atlantis plate.â€Â  Approximately three and a half months post-surgery, Dr. Oetting completed an affidavit in which he acknowledged that Murrayâ€™s â€œhistory of being injured at work was consistent with [his] findings of two disc ruptures at C5-6 centrally, and C6-7 to the right.â€Â  Dr. Oetting further noted that Murray had not reached maximum medical improvement as of the date of the affidavit. Â Â Â 
Murray filed a Form 50 to receive workerâ€™s compensation benefits for his injury. Â Employer denied the claim and disputed whether the injury occurred at work. Â After a hearing, the single commissioner found Murray suffered a compensable injury to his neck and right arm on April 20, 2003.Â  In reaching this decision, the commissioner specifically found Murrayâ€™s testimony to be credible. Â Based on these findings, the commissioner ordered Employer to pay Murray medical expenses as well as temporary total disability benefits beginning on April 24, 2003, the day Murray stopped working, until further order of the Commission.Â  
The Full Commission unanimously affirmed the order of the single commissioner.Â  On appeal, the circuit court affirmed the decision of the Full Commission.Â  In its order, the circuit court noted that Employer â€œessentially admits that Mr. Murray injured his neck at work; however, the employer contends Mr. Murrayâ€™s neck injury was idiopathic and, therefore, did not arise out of his work.â€Â  The court rejected this contention and found that â€œ[w]hen â€˜considering all the circumstancesâ€™ relating to Mr. Murrayâ€™s neck injury, there is certainly substantial evidence of a causal connection between the conditions under which the work is required to be performed and the resulting injury.â€Â  The court further stated â€œthere is substantial evidence that Mr. Murray was performing a physically demanding job requiring him to work hurriedly between machines, bend, go up and down steps and the injury occurred when he twisted his neck to move quickly between machines to keep them operational, which was a requirement of his job.â€Â  
Employer appeals the decision of the circuit court.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission. Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981). â€œIn workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder.â€ Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  The Full Commission is specifically reserved the task of assessing the credibility of the witnesses and the weight to be accorded evidence. Id. 
â€œAccordingly, this Court will not substitute its judgment for that of the commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.â€ Therrell v. Jerryâ€™s Inc., 370 S.C. 22, ___, 633 S.E.2d 893, 894 (2006). Â â€œ[T]his Court may reverse or modify the commissionâ€™s decision if Petitioner has suffered the appropriate degree of prejudice and the commissionâ€™s decision is effected by an error of law or is â€˜clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative and substantial evidence on the whole record.â€™â€ Id. at ___, 633 S.E.2d at 895 (quoting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(2005)).Â  â€œIt is not within our province to reverse findings of the Commission which are supported by substantial evidence.â€ Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 496, 520 S.E.2d 634, 637 (Ct. App. 1999).
DISCUSSION
I.
Employer argues the circuit court erred in finding that Murrayâ€™s injury arose out of his employment.Â  Employer contends Murray failed to prove there was a causal connection between his work activities and the cervical disc ruptures. Â We disagree.
In order to receive workersâ€™ compensation benefits, Murray must prove that he sustained an â€œinjury by accident arising out of and in the course of the employment.â€ S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (Supp. 2005).Â  â€œThe term â€˜arose out ofâ€™ refers to the origin of the cause of the accident, while the term â€˜in the course ofâ€™ refers to the time, place, and circumstances under which the accident occurred.â€ Howell v. Pac. Columbia Mills, 291 S.C. 469, 471, 354 S.E.2d 384, 385 (1987).Â  â€œAlthough the requirements are somewhat overlapping, they are not synonymous and both must exist simultaneously to allow the claimant to recover.â€ Gibson v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. #3, 338 S.C. 510, 518, 526 S.E.2d 725, 729 (Ct. App. 2000).
â€œThe injury arises out of employment when there is a causal connection between the conditions under which the work is required to be performed and the resulting injury.â€ Broughton v. South of the Border, 336 S.C. 488, 497, 520 S.E.2d 634, 638 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  â€œAn injury occurs â€˜in the course ofâ€™ employment within the meaning of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act when it occurs within the period of employment at a place where the employee reasonably may be in the performance of his duties and while fulfilling those duties or engaged in something incidental thereto.â€Â  Id. at 498, 520 S.E.2d at 639.Â  
â€œWhether there is any causal connection between employment and an injury is a question of fact for the Commission.â€Â  Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 159, 519 S.E.2d 102, 105 (1999).Â  â€œBecause causation is a question of fact, the full commissionâ€™s decision on the issue must be affirmed if it is supported by substantial evidence in the record.â€ Shuler v. Gregory Elec., 366 S.C. 435, 440, 622 S.E.2d 569, 571 (Ct. App. 2005).
Therefore, we must affirm the Commissionâ€™s ruling unless it is clearly erroneous in view of the substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Nettles v. Spartanburg Sch. Dist. #7, 341 S.C. 580, 586, 535 S.E.2d 146, 149 (Ct. App. 2000).Â Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is â€˜not a mere scintilla of evidence nor the evidence viewed blindly from one side of the case, but is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached or must have reached in order to justify its action.â€™â€Â  Miller by Miller v. State Roofing Co., 312 S.C. 452, 454, 441 S.E.2d 323, 324-25 (1994) (quoting Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 135, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981)).Â  â€œThe substantial evidence rule does not allow judicial fact-finding, or the substitution of judicial judgment for agency judgment.Â  A judgment upon which reasonable men might differ will not be set aside.â€Â  Toddâ€™s Ice Cream, Inc. v. South Carolina Employment Sec. Commâ€™n, 281 S.C. 254, 258, 315 S.E.2d 373, 375 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  However, â€œ[w]here there is a conflict in the evidence, either of different witnesses or of the same witnesses, the findings of fact of the Commission as triers of the fact are conclusive.â€Â  Holcombe v. Dan River Mills/Woodside Div., 286 S.C. 223, 225, 333 S.E.2d 338, 340 (Ct. App. 1985).
Our review of the record indicates there was substantial evidence to support the Commissionâ€™s finding that Murrayâ€™s injury arose out of his employment.[2]Â  Murrayâ€™s employment as a slotter required him to walk, bend, stoop, squat, climb, push, pull, reach, twist and turn to keep operational the three machines for which he was responsible. Â Based on these work-related actions, Murray acknowledged that his job was â€œrather physical.â€ Â He further stated that he had to move between the machines in a â€œhurry fashion.â€Â  At the time of the injury, Murray was in the process of performing these tasks.Â  Murray testified his job required him to work at a â€œsteady paceâ€ and walk in a â€œhurryâ€ to keep the frames running.Â  At the time of the injury, Murray testified he was fixing an end on machine number eight when he noticed a problem with machine number nine.Â  He stated that he hurt his neck and his arm when he stepped down and then twisted and turned to work on machine number nine. 
Significantly, Murray further testified that he had no physical problems prior to the accident and had already worked approximately nine hours of his twelve-hour shift. Â Murray also testified, and supported with documentation, that he had an excellent, twenty-three-year work history which included several years of perfect attendance. Â Finally, Dr. Oetting, Murrayâ€™s treating neurosurgeon, stated in an affidavit that â€œMr. Murrayâ€™s history of being injured at work was consistent with [his] findings of two disc ruptures at C5-6 centrally, and C6-7 to the right.â€ Â Thus, there is substantial evidence that Murrayâ€™s injury was related to the performance of his employment duties.
Additionally, we reject Employerâ€™s contention that Murrayâ€™s injury was not compensable because it was similar to cases where our appellate courts declined to compensate an employee who suffered an idiopathic fall while at work. See, e.g., Bagwell v. Ernest Burwell, Inc., 227 S.C. 444, 450, 888 S.E.2d 611, 613-14 (1955) (denying compensation where claimant failed to show any causal connection between the fall of the deceased and his employment when evidence indicated that deceasedâ€™s fall occurred while he was standing at his desk and â€œwas due to some internal failure or weaknessâ€); Miller v. Springs Cotton Mills, 225 S.C. 326, 330, 82 S.E.2d 458, 459 (1954) (finding claimant failed to show injury by accident arising out of and in the course of her employment where claimantâ€™s injury, which occurred in employerâ€™s cafeteria while she was eating lunch, was the result of â€œsome internal failure or breakdown in the knee which might have happened at any timeâ€); Crosby v. Wal-Mart Store, Inc., 330 S.C. 489, 493, 499 S.E.2d 253, 256 (Ct. App. 1998) (holding claimant not entitled to benefits because claimant failed to show causal connection between her fall and her employment where evidence indicated that claimant fell while walking on level floor in employerâ€™s store).Â  Unlike the above-cited cases, Murrayâ€™s injury occurred while he was performing the physical demands of maintaining the operation of the three frames.Â  In contrast, the employees in the cases cited by Employer were injured from an unexplained fall from walking on a level floor or a fall from a blackout.Â  
Furthermore, the fact that Murray was not carrying, pushing, or lifting something, as Employer proposes is a necessary requirement, at the time of the injury is not dispositive of whether he was entitled to compensation.Â  We discern no such requirement under the standard of â€œarising out ofâ€ the course of employment.Â  See Ellis v. Spartan Mills, 276 S.C. 216, 219, 277 S.E.2d 590, 592 (1981) (finding claimant was entitled to compensation where evidence established that claimant, a loom operator, suffered her back injury during a work activity when she bent forward to retrieve a thread that was lying on the floor); Â Â Sigmon v. Dayco Corp., 316 S.C. 260, 262, 449 S.E.2d 497, 498 (Ct. App. 1994) (recognizing that â€œan injury by accidentâ€ does not necessarily require a causative event and stating â€œthe unexpected result or industrial injury is itself considered the compensable accidentâ€).
II.
Employer asserts the circuit court erred in finding that Murray was injured when he twisted his neck at work.Â  Specifically, Employer argues â€œthere is absolutely no testimony that Claimant injured his neck as he was â€˜hurriedly raisingâ€™ up from being bent over, or that he was twisting his neck at the time of the injury.â€Â  Employer claims there are no facts to support that finding and, thus, it was reversible error to conclude that Murrayâ€™s claim was compensable.Â  We disagree.
As outlined above, Murray testified that he was in a hurry and working at a steady pace at the time of his injury. Â He also acknowledged that there was a â€œsense of urgencyâ€ when he went between machine number eight and machine number nine at the time of the injury.Â  Additionally, Murray testified that he hurt his neck and arm when he turned and twisted while going toward machine number nine.Â  He also stated that he felt pain in his neck and arm during the process of going between the two frames.Â  Murray specifically testified that he felt the pain â€œ[a]s soon [as] I turned, I twisted.â€Â  As previously stated, Dr. Oetting found that the history of the injury given by Murray was consistent with his findings of the two disc ruptures. Â Furthermore, the single commissionerâ€™s order, which was unanimously affirmed by the Full Commission, found Murray to be a â€œvery credible witness.â€Â  Accordingly, we reject Employerâ€™s claim that the circuit court mischaracterized the facts to reach the conclusion that Murrayâ€™s injury was compensable.
Based on the foregoing, the order of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON, HUFF, and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1] Because oral argument would not aid the court in resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  Employer does not appear to challenge whether Murrayâ€™s injury occurred in the course of his employment.Â  In its brief, Employer contends the injury â€œmerely happened at work but it was not caused by work.â€Â  Accordingly, we confine our analysis to a determination of whether the injury arose out of Murrayâ€™s employment.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Gary Lee Willard, Claimant, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        ASCO Valve Manufacturing, Employer, and Emerson Electric Company, Carrier, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Aiken CountyÂ 
Doyet A. Early, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-384
Submitted November 1, 2006 â€“ Filed November 27, 2006Â Â Â  

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Stephen B. Samuels, McWhirter Bellinger, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Clarke W. McCants, III, Nance & McCants, of Aiken, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation case, the circuit court reversed the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commissionâ€™s award of benefits to the claimant, concluding that Commissionâ€™s findings were not supported by substantial evidence.Â  We reverse and remand to the circuit court to reinstate the Commissionâ€™s judgment.[1]Â  
I.
On December 7, 2000, Gary Lee Willard (claimant) injured his neck and left shoulder during the scope and course of his employment with ASCO Valve Manufacturing (the employer). Â The employer and the insurance carrier (Emerson Electric Company) accepted the claim and provided benefits.Â  Claimant initially received treatment for his injury from his family doctor, Dr. James Bland.Â  Claimant continued to work for employer in a light duty status until March 2001, at which point he returned to full duty status.Â  
In a report dated February 4, 2002, Dr. James L. Becton, an orthopedic surgeon, opined that Claimant had reached maximum medical improvement and sustained a zero percent permanent physical impairment.Â  Â Â Dr. Bectonâ€™s assessment was consistent with an earlier (June 19, 2001) report by Dr. Ildemaro Volcan.Â  On February 5, 2002, claimant received notice that â€œit is the opinion of the insurer and employer that you have reached maximum medical improvement and . . . your workersâ€™ compensation claim is being closed.â€ Â 
In May of 2002, the ASCO plant underwent a layoff.Â  The layoff was announced company wide on May 7, 2002.Â  In a memorandum dated May 10, Claimant was informed that his specific position would be eliminated on May 28th.Â  Claimant was given the choice of (1) working a lower-paying job within the company or (2) accepting the layoff.Â  On May 14, claimant selected the second option, but also wrote on the form: â€œBY SIGNING THIS, I AM NOT AGREEING TO A VOLUNTARY LAYOFF. Â I AM ONLY AGREEING TO THE CHOICE OF PAY.â€ 
Claimant last worked for employer on May 15, 2002; however, his departure was not under the terms of the layoff.Â  Claimant sought additional treatment from Dr. Bland on May 7, 2002.Â  On May 20, 2002, Dr. Bland wrote claimant out of work as of May 17, 2002 with a projected return to work on May 28, 2002 â€œor longer depending onâ€ a neurosurgical evaluation.Â  Dr. Blandâ€™s report noted claimantâ€™s assertion of â€œpain in neck and left arm.â€Â  Dr. Bland declined, however, to opine on whether claimantâ€™s injury was work related, deferring that determination to a neurosurgical evaluation.Â  In this regard, Dr. Bland referred claimant to Dr. Richard Mendel, a neurosurgeon.Â  It is undisputed that claimant was not forthright with Dr. Bland about his work history.Â  
Dr. Mendel evaluated claimant on May 8, 2002 and August 29, 2002.Â  In a report dated August 29, 2002, Dr. Mendel noted Claimantâ€™s MRI â€œin fact demonstrates a fragmented disc at the C6-7 level on the left.â€Â  Beyond claimantâ€™s objective injury, it is clear from Dr. Mendelâ€™s report that claimant lied to Dr. Mendel about his work historyâ€”telling Dr. Mendel he had not been able to work for two years. Â 
On November 27, 2002, claimant was seen by Dr. Donald R. Johnson, a neurosurgeon.Â  Dr. Johnsonâ€™s review of claimantâ€™s May 29, 2002 MRI reflected â€œa high quality study and shows a clear left sided herniation at C6-C7.â€Â  It was Dr. Johnsonâ€™s opinion that claimant had not reached maximum medical improvement.Â  Dr. Johnson recommended surgery, and stated claimant should return to work only after surgery.Â  As with the other doctors, claimant was not completely forthright with Dr. Johnson concerning his work history.Â 
II.
In July 2002, claimant filed a Form 50 seeking additional medical treatment (for his neck, back, arm and hand) and temporary total disability benefits.Â  The employer filed a Form 51, denying the claim on the grounds Claimant had reached maximum medical improvement.Â  
Following a hearing, the single commissioner found claimant had sustained a â€œ20% permanent partial disability to [his] neckâ€ and awarded compensation accordingly.Â  The single commissioner further found claimant had reached maximum medical improvement on February 4, 2002, and was not entitled to further medical treatment nor temporary compensation.Â  In so ruling, the single commissioner credited the evidence submitted by the employer.Â  
The single commissionerâ€™s decision was appealed to an appellate panel of the Commission (the Commission).Â  The Commission found claimant had not reached maximum medical improvement and was entitled to further medical treatment as well as temporary total benefits from November 27, 2002.Â  The Commission referenced the testimony of Dr. Johnson in finding claimant had not reached maximum medical improvement and awarding temporary total disability compensation.[2]Â  
The parties appealed to the circuit court, with the employer challenging the Commissionâ€™s findings regarding maximum medical improvement and entitlement to benefits and claimant challenging the November 27, 2002 start date.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s view of the evidence mirrored that of the single commissioner, as the circuit court â€œconclude[d] that the evidence in this matter fully supports [the single commissionerâ€™s] findingsâ€ and â€œmodifiedâ€ the Commissionâ€™s order â€œin accordance with such ruling [of the single commissioner].â€Â  Claimant appeals.
III.
The Administrative Procedures Act establishes the standard of review for decisions by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134-35, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  â€œIn workersâ€™ compensation cases, the Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder.â€Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  Neither the circuit court nor this court may substitute its judgment for that of the Commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6).[3] As relevant to this case, the appellate court may reverse or modify the Commissionâ€™s decision only if the claimantâ€™s substantial rights have been prejudiced because the decision is affected by an error of law or is clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative, and substantial evidence on the whole record.Â  Id.Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is not a mere scintilla of evidence nor evidence viewed from one side, but such evidence, when the whole record is considered, as would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the Full Commission reached.â€Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.
IV.
Claimant first asserts that the circuit court erred by making its own findings of fact regarding claimantâ€™s right to receive temporary total disability (TTD) compensation.Â  We agree.
The resolution of this appeal is controlled by the deferential substantial evidence scope of review.Â  The circuit court, sitting in its appellate capacity, engaged in impermissible fact-finding.Â  Because there is evidence to support the conclusion reached by the Commission, we are constrained (as was the circuit court) to sustain the findings of the Commission.Â  That the evidence may reasonably be viewed to preponderate toward the view advocated by the circuit court provides no basis or license to circumvent the substantial evidence scope of review.Â  Moreover, when the evidence is in conflict, as here, the substantial evidence test forecloses the re-weighing of evidence.
The circuit court held that â€œa valid medical opinion exists only when supported by a reliable and accurate history.Â  Absent such a history the opinion is, at best, questionable and of limited value.â€Â  Determining whether a medical opinionâ€”or any evidenceâ€”is â€œvalidâ€ or of â€œvalueâ€ strikes at the heart of the Commissionâ€™s mandated fact-finding role.Â  Moreover, it appears the circuit courtâ€™s take on the evidence is premised on the belief that claimantâ€™s entitlement to relief hinged solely on his credibility, especially as to his subjective complaints.Â  Such a view ignores the objective basisâ€”namely, the results of claimantâ€™s MRIâ€”of the opinions of Drs. Mendel and Johnson.Â Â  When the record as a whole is examined in light of the proper standard of review on appeal, the findings of the Commission (that claimant has not reached maximum medical improvement and is entitled to temporary total disability) are supported by substantial evidence.Â  We thus reverse the circuit court.
V.
Claimant next appeals the November 27, 2002 start date for TTD as determined by the Commission.Â  
While we appreciate the basis of claimantâ€™s argument for the May 17, 2002 start date, we cannot say the Commissionâ€™s selection of November 27 falls below the substantial evidence test.Â  In this regard, the Commission could have reasonably elected not to credit claimantâ€™s testimony as to the unusual circumstances surrounding his departure from work in May.Â  While Dr. Bland opined claimant was unable to work as of May 17 based on claimantâ€™s subjective complaints, it was only Dr. Johnson who offered a definitive opinion concerning claimants inability to work based on objective findingsâ€”noting on November 27, 2002, after review of the MRI, that â€œ[t]he patient has certainly not reached maximum medical improvement and I feel should not be returned to the workplace until he has had the necessary surgery done.â€Â  Although the circuit court was critical of the Commissionâ€™s reliance on the â€œsingular evidenceâ€ of Dr. Johnson, reasonable minds could certainly reject claimantâ€™s reliance on Dr. Bland for a May 17 start date for TTD when one considers that Dr. Bland suggested a â€œreturn to work dateâ€ of May 28, 2002.Â  In addition, Dr. Bland expressly declined to offer an opinion as to whether claimantâ€™s injury was work related, opting to defer to a neurosurgical evaluation.Â  Accordingly, we reject claimantâ€™s challenge to the November 27, 2002 start date for TTD.
VI.
For the reasons stated above, the order of the circuit court is reversed and the matter is remanded to the circuit court to reinstate the judgment of the Commission.
REVERSED and REMANDED.
KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., and CURETON, A.J., concur.Â Â 

[1] Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  The employerâ€™s carrier subsequently agreed to pay for claimantâ€™s surgery.
[3] This code section was amended by Act No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 387; however, the applicable language at all times pertinent to the present appeal is found in section 1-23-680(A)(6) of the South Carolina Code (2005).

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS 
 PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
York Printing & Finishing, Inc. and Bonnie Watts,
Respondents,
v.
Springs Industries, Inc., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2006-UP-385
Heard November 9, 2006 â€“ Filed November 27, 2006Â Â Â 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Benjamin A. Johnson and Stephen M. Cox, of Rock Hill, for Appellant.
Christopher L. Murphy and James A. Stuckey, Jr., of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Springs Industries, Inc. (â€œSpringsâ€) appeals a jury verdict for York Printing & Finishing, Inc. and Bonnie Watts (collectively â€œYork Printingâ€).Â  Springs argues the trial court erred in denying its motions for directed verdict and JNOV because Springs owed no duty of care to York Printing and York Printing put forth no evidence demonstrating Springsâ€™ negligent misrepresentation proximately caused York Printingâ€™s business failure.Â  Springs also argues the trial court erred in denying its unclean hands defense.Â  We affirm.Â Â  
1.Â  Springs argues the trial court erred in denying its directed verdict motion on York Printingâ€™s cause of action for negligent misrepresentation because Springs owed no legal duty to York Printing.Â  The determination of the existence of a duty is a question of law.Â  Faile v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Juvenile Justice, 350 S.C. 315, 334, 566 S.E.2d 536, 545 (2002).Â  â€œA duty to exercise reasonable care in giving information exists when the defendant has a pecuniary interest in the transaction.â€Â  Winburn v. Ins. Co. of N. Am., 287 S.C. 435, 441, 339 S.E.2d 142, 146 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  Further, if the defendant â€œpossesses expertise or special knowledge that would ordinarily make it reasonable for another to rely on his judgment or ability to make careful enquiry, the law places on him a duty of care with respect to representations made to plaintiff.â€Â  AMA Mgmt. Corp. v. Strasburger, 309 S.C. 213, 223, 420 S.E.2d 868, 874 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  Here, after Duke Power refused to provide information (citing privacy concerns) to York Printing regarding Springsâ€™ monthly utility costs for the Bleachery, York Printing turned to Springs for this informationâ€”information critical to York Printingâ€™s decision to proceed with the purchase of the Bleachery.Â  With a clear understanding of the importance of this information to York Printing, Springs provided York Printing with a chart of the Bleacheryâ€™s monthly utility costs for the preceding year, including the critical months of July and August of 1998.Â  This utility chart contained materially false information.Â  Springs had a pecuniary interest not only in selling the Bleachery to York Printing, but also in leasing-back portions of the Bleachery after the sale (and after York Printing agreed to pay for the Bleacheryâ€™s utility costs).Â  Springs possessed special knowledgeâ€”the Bleacheryâ€™s actual monthly utility costs for the preceding yearâ€”that York Printing could not obtain elsewhere.Â  Therefore, Springs had a duty to exercise reasonable care when it provided York Printing the utility chart.Â  Accordingly, the trial court properly denied Springsâ€™ directed verdict motion.
2.Â  Springs argues the trial court erred in denying its directed verdict motion on York Printingâ€™s cause of action for negligent misrepresentation because York Printing offered no evidence showing Springs proximately caused York Printingâ€™s business failure.Â  â€œOrdinarily, the question of proximate cause is one of fact for the jury and the trial judgeâ€™s sole function regarding the issue is to inquire whether particular conclusions are the only reasonable inferences that can be drawn from the evidence.â€Â  McNair v. Rainsford, 330 S.C. 332, 349, 499 S.E.2d 488, 497 (Ct. App. 1998).Â  Evidence in the record supports the juryâ€™s finding that York Printingâ€™s business failure was the natural and probable consequence of Springsâ€™ false representationâ€”the gross understatement of the Bleacheryâ€™s electric bills.Â  York Printing presented evidence that it relied on Springsâ€™ utility chart, particularly the figures for the two months prior to York Printingâ€™s purchase of the Bleachery to determine whether it could turn a profit.Â  The record shows Springs understood the importance of these figures to York Printing, and York Printing relied on these figures to its detriment.Â  When the correct amounts are considered, two facts can be concluded.Â  First, York Printing would not have purchased the Bleachery had it known the true electric bills.Â  Second, the failure of York Printing may be attributed to its inability to operate profitably in light of the true electric bills.Â  These conclusions satisfy the element of proximate cause.Â  Accordingly, the trial court properly denied Springsâ€™ directed verdict motion and submitted the claim to the jury.
3.Â  Springs argues the trial court erred in denying its unclean hands defense.Â  Where an equitable defense is raised against a legal action, the trial judge has the â€œresponsibility of making findings of fact as to the equitable defense.â€Â  Huguenin v. Wall, 279 S.C. 518, 521, 309 S.E.2d 794, 795 (Ct. App. 1983).Â  In such cases, the scope of review on appeal is de novo.Â  Id.Â  Here, Springs presents two pieces of evidence that it believes demonstrates York Printingâ€™s unclean hands.Â  First, York Printing represented to its lender that it had verbal commitments from purchasers to buy from York Printing after it began operations in the Bleachery, and Springs contends no such verbal commitments existed.Â  Second, York Printing represented to the federal government that it intended to create one hundred new jobs at the Bleachery, and Springs contends York Printing had no intention of creating that many new jobs.Â  The trial court found the facts of the case did not give rise to an unclean hands defense.Â  The record fully supports this finding.Â  Moreover, Springs cannot complain of York Printingâ€™s dealings with third parties, because the clean hands maxim does not apply to matters outside the transaction between plaintiff and defendant.Â  Arnold v. City of Spartanburg, 201 S.C. 523, 532, 23 S.E.2d 735, 738 (S.C. 1943) (â€œThe expression â€˜clean handsâ€™ means a clean record with respect to the transaction with the defendants themselves and not with respect to others.â€).Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not err in rejecting the unclean hands defense.
The judgment pursuant to the jury verdict is 
 AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., and KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.
